reviewText:
This is the first review I am doing for a game. Now to get to my rating it's a fun game for people that are lvl 70. With saying that I am talking about PvP in the game. They have enough AD to buy rank 7 ruins that make the game unfair to new players. They can pretty much almost one shot you.

As for the PvE content it's fun to about level 60. There are only 4 dungoens you can run till you hit 70 so not much to do there. From 1 to 60 it's a straight forward quest line to level you pretty fast beleave I hit 60 in about two weeks or three about 1 to 2 hours a day. From 60 to 70 it is a big grind fest and that's hard since you get almost no exp for killing mobs you get your exp from quest. They do have their daily quest that you can do but even with them it took about 5 hours or so just to level from 60 to 61.

Classes seem kinda broken they are all OP in their own way and that really kills PvP also but a good thing for PvE since you can solo all the way to 70 if you wanted too. Treats seem to be broken or just do nothing. As a tank I maxed out my CC Res so I would get hit lease but seems like everyone I come across stuns, roots, and whatever to me no problem. Then healers and the rouge classes can dodge almost every stun I can and then I have to play cat and mouse with them and by time I catch them I am already half dead and I can't get any skills off since they keep stunning me. I also maxed out the increse to the CC I do and it still does nothing for me. It just feels like stats are broken in this game and the only thing that matters are the ruins you put into your armor.

Over all it's not the worse MMORPG I've played but it's not the best. I would rather stick with the real Dungoens and Dragons MMORPG for a free to play game. As for PvP I thought SWTOR was the worse but I was wrong. I give it a 4.5/10 And the stronghold like someone else said you need to be on a real active guild unless you can't even enjoy that.

reviewText:
Dungeons & Dragons: Neverwinter is based on the AD&D 4.0 Core Ruleset, and I think that it's done rather well. The graphics, sounds, music, and locations are well developed & quite immersive too. Cryptic Studios made an amazing free-to-play (F2P) game, and you don't have to spend any real world money to level from 1-60; The game is not restrictive in anyway whatsoever.

The character models are well detailed, and the combat movement are very engaging - albeit they could be more fluid. Combat itself is great to play, and I love that there are no auto-attack moves/spells; Everything must be done by the player in real time. In this case with regards to combat and action, you [the player] stay involved, focused, and must be have situational awareness -- something that I like very much.

To me the only downsides to this game are the ridiculously over-priced items in the Zen Market, and the difficulty in acquiring Astral Diamonds. For the latter it may not be a problem for the very active player, but casual players are at a disadvantage IMO. I also personally feel that many of the zones are very linear, and closed-in - leaving no open world exploring in what I'd like in an MMORPG.

Overall the game is a must-have to play for those that enjoy Fantasy RPG's. There's very little to be disappointed with here. I highly recommend this game, especially if you're looking for something F2P.

reviewText: Another franchise ruined by cryptic, first STO(star trek online), now D&D's Neverwinter, cryptic has done it again, managed to turn a great franchise into a shamefull, shallow, turn-key, coin-operated money machine.  Having beta'd STO i'm familiar to this nickel and diming by cryptic, and yes it is absolutely PAY to win, not truly play for free, as you can play for free but dont expect to be any good, regardless of your skill with your char, you will be at the mercy of people with PAY items which are substantially better than their non paid counterparts.  The game is a formulaic mmorpg, borrowing genre standards from various games, including some unique features like action style combat(gets boring quickly imho) and the abilitiy to create your own quests, which is the only thing about this game i actually like.  It is too under whelming, an extremely shallow d&d experience, sharing little but images and names of its original, deeper and more complex counterpart, for having sacrificed so much of what a D&D experience is, it is also inexcuseably boring and repetitive.  Cryptic definately didnt push itself to accomplish anything that would be a landmark experience, it feels like its the exact opposite, like a game done for a quick pay cheque.

reviewText:
(THIS WAS REVIEWED IN OCT 2014, OBVIOUSLY THE GAMES CHANGED)


The endgame is very limited and the games requirements to getting its own advantages to making it easier for you (horses, enchantments, armor, etc.) are overly exaggerated to the point where either playing or paying is a loss.
The questing to get to LVL 60 can be done in under 6-10 hours, containing underdeveloped areas strictly for PVE and some dungeons which have balancing issues and require an amount of specific classes to complete.

The classes you start with contain problems and balancing and have a distinct difference which determines how useless or how useful you are. Some people wouldn't want a guardian in their dungeon run because of the tanking being useless to a boss enemy that will just overwhelm you with damage and aggro imediately, but would want a guardian for PVP because of the defense it has, making the person who intialy chose that class rather regretful. The mages do a lot of DPS damage which makes them a favorable class.

There are anomalies in this game that are aggrevating to see. PVE mini bosses sometimes dropped themed armor pieces that have better stats by a little but look very cool to edit, but sometimes you can get a guardians armor as a mage and this armor cannot be sold, traded, only worn and destroyed. But... you can't wear it either... so yea. The currency is limited also, where as after lvl 60, astral diamonds would become your main currency where as the coins would just be petty money to buy potions.

The end game is very small and limited and will only have you playing for about one or two weeks before realizing what you're doing everyday is farming for goals like higher gear-rank, enchantments, wealth, mounts, armor, campaigns, which honestly don't open anymore of the game to you after thats completed.

I have not seen this level of incompetence by a development team since the craptastic closed betas, and releases, of Vanguard and Age of Conan. The biggest, and most abused lie they spread, is that the changes are meant to stop bots and black market trade of Astral diamonds--every chnage they have made has only given more reason for players to make purchases from the black market and has done nothing to stop the infestation of bots.

reviewText: Neverwinter was once an Amazing game! Unfortunatly, module 5 brought many unwelcome changes. I have played since Module 3, (through Arc) and thouroly enjoyed it. Most of the positive reviews are prior to Module 5, so do not be fooled. Before Module 5, dungeons dropped loot to sell in the Auction House. The gap between moderate and well geared players was there, but not too prominent. The P2W factor was there, but it was rather controlled. Now... Dungeons drop currency used to buy BOP gear. Many dungeons were just completely removed from the game. Many maps are recycled. Seriouslt, 1 map is the same as another map, just upside down... Many mini dungeons are identicle top module 3 mini dungeons (with different monsters..). The new Strongholds expansion has completly destroyed the smaller guilds, as people left to join bigger guilds that could offer better Stats/boons (since when should a guild affiliation grant stat bonuses?!). The new higher level enchantments are extremely difficult and time consuming to grind for unless you pay money to buy supplies to refine them faster. The new VIP Program gives extra HP to member who pay for monthly VIP status. There are new artifact weapons every 2-4 months so the gear you do grind for is obsolete too quickly. When you refine your old artifact gear into the new sets, they only salvage about 75% of the original refinement points. Every time you buy something new in this game, it is nerfed (google teneborous enchantment). The PVP matchmaking is a disaster. I am constantly matched up against premade BIS players from the largest PVP guilds with the best boons. Solo queing into PVP will result in failure 9/10 times, as it COMPLETELY IGNORES differences in gear. This means a new lvl 70nplayer will be thrown to the wolves" if he/she tries to pvp. I highly reccomend you stay clear of this game untill these huge issues are fixed. Definately save your money. Lvls 1-60 are decietfully fun and easy. Lvl 61 hits like a bus. The grind to lvl 70 takes forever. Please do not be fooled. Read the official neverwinter forums if you have any doubts."

reviewText:
Despite being a D&D Forgotten Realms license this is actually a trick to get fans to download it, you download the game and it's barely D&D at all, if you're a fan of other games in Neverwinter the city itself looks cool but even the plot is bad for the setting. Even if you take the setting and plot issues out of the equation and look at it on its own the game mechanics aren't great, action combat has been done much better in other games that didn't try to ruin a pre-existing license.

+ Cool to walk around Neverwinter city in an MMO
+ Flashy graphics

- Setting/license and gameplay disconnect
- Continuity issues with the setting
- Stupid things hidden behind paywall
- Lame plot that doesn't hook you in enough

If you want a good D&D MMO, just try DDO because even with all its faults it's still better and needs more players anyway.

reviewText:
I've played this game for about 20 hours now. I leveled a Half-Elf ranger from level 1-40, and I can't say I recommend this game right now. In a lot of ways, NW falls short of the WoW watermark, and that's a shame, because I was hoping it would be a good successor to DDO and WoW as an MMO great.

Let me say that on my SLI GTX 760s I did not experience any stutter. The game didn't even access more than 30% of these cards during play, which makes me think this could be played on a tablet if someone wanted to. Which is good if you don't have a system with great specs.

Secondly, the game's visuals are only okay by 2010-2011 standards. This was released in 2013, and in 2016, it looks bad. Graphics are very flat with no shadows, no specular highlights, and no volumetric fog at all. Player meshes look like they were designed for cell phone support. Overall, visually, this is the worst MMO I've played in a great while.

But that wouldn't be a reason that I wouldn't recommend it, that comes in with the gameplay, and its annoyances start to become more apparent the longer you play and come into your class. As a ranger specializing in archery, I progressed through the game, but found myself fighting with the mechanics of the game more than the monsters. Either a mob would path behind a wall and I'd lose my shot on them, or the skill that I chose to control aggro of mobs just wasn't all that good. One of the rooting shots in the Hunter tree roots for about 1 second, even on rank 3/4...(You don't gain access to the 4th tier of abilities until level 70).

But the main reason why I won't be playing this too much longer is because of the game's broken companion AI. It's terrible. You can't set your pet to aggressive, passive, or neutral. And that makes it impossible to use the companion as a tank. On average, my companion was able to pull aggro on 2/5 of every mob set I went into. That's simply not good enough. You can't even tell the pet to attack before you shoot your bow, so you have basically no control over aggro whatsoever. With my reduced threat perk maxed, I always wound up with enemies charging at me, and running out of stamina too quickly.

There were times when I would trigger combat intentionally, wait for the companion to charge in and get some hits, then I would retreat to max bow range only to have the companion disengage for no reason and come running to me. I don't get it. This would happen in crypt-sized dungeons as well as outdoor maps.

In addition, around level 40, the game starts setting you up with obvious AMBUSH chokepoints on the map, which antagonize your abilities to no end. Hunter/Archer skills are about keeping an enemy at range, and when you have to walk onto a trigger point where 10 enemies pop in surrounding you on all sides at point blank range, it makes everything in your action bar kind of pointless.

Bottom line, if you're going to do this, don't play a ranged class unless you have a friend dedicated to going through the quests with you. It's pointless, and I just wasted 20 hours figuring that out. Until they fix these issues, I can't recommend Neverwinter.

reviewText:
I had a difficult time figuring out whether i would give this a thumbs up or down. After much thought, I decided on a thumbs down.

If you are the type of gamer that is willing to put hundreds of hours into one toon and still not get your toon super geared out, then this game will work very well for you.

If you the type that likes to get there relatively quick, then this might not be the game for you, and if you are an altaholic, then this game most definitely is not for you. Don't even bother.

This game started out very well. Very strong, and had plenty of potential. The graphics were and always have been kind of dated, but the gameplay for a while made up for that. And the storyline, if you chose to read everything, was very compelling.

The biggest problem really goes into what I explained first. This game kind of caters to a particular niche. For the hardcore grinders. Thats about it. They have not been able to find a happy medium to draw a generic crowd. That's about really it, and that is enough for me not to recomend this in general.

reviewText:
This review is currently in progress and should only be taken as a first impression of the game.

Graphics: 7
Gritty and decently realistic, but textures are unusually low quality and character models are a bit chunky.

Sound: 7
Average sound, not bad, not good.  Has decent voice overs.

Gameplay: 5
Combat similair to Tera online except you can't move while attacking, only dodge moves.  It suffers the same problem as Tera online that it's just hiding the targeting from you, but still auto targets whichever monster is closest to your cursor when you attack.  This is extremly obvious on a ranger where the split arrow move is very difficult to aim as you can't aim between enemies to hit them both, when you right click your camera auto targets one of the enemies making the attack less accurate.
Like every other MMO, it follows the questing format that we've all grown bored of.

Impression: 3
As an MMO it doesn't break any new ground that hasn't already been broken by Tera online.  The graphics are lower than some newer MMO's, the combat is slower, and the quests are still boring.  The game makes a vague attempt to play to neverwinter lore, but then falls appart with pre-made canned characters removing the ability to apply dungeons and dragons like upgrades.  If you were hoping to roll your own character, play Dungeons and Dragons online instead which does a much better job of letting you roll play your own character.

Value: ?
Unknown, haven't played long enough.

Summary (In progress):
I see no reason for this game to exist, the same formula has been used countless times before.  If your in this for the social aspect, play the game the rest of your friends are playing.  If your looking for D&D style roll playing, play D&D Online.  If your looking for active combat, play Tera online or Vindictus.

reviewText:
You can check out my full review of Neverwinter Online here[uncrownedreview.blogspot.com]

I'd like to say that I don't think Neverwinter Online is inherently pay to win. Sure there are pay to win elements in the game that could easily be stamped out but that's not the most offensive part of this game.

Let me tell you a story. Imagine a game called Neverwinter Online. In this fantasy world there was a beta server that a company called Cryptic set up specifically to test for bugs in upcoming patches and updates.

A new class called the Hunter Ranger is scheduled to appear in the next update, but something is off about it. Every so often the stars will align and particle effects from a specific ability of the Hunter Ranger will not go away, lagging and crashing instances as particles are spewed out. Very frustrating, but Cryptic knows just what to do! It releases the Hunter Ranger and doesn't warn anyone about the known bugs and glitches with the class! For almost 3 weeks straight, instances are lagging and crashing as the players discover this bug for themselves. Finally, Cryptic decides to go ahead and patch the problem. It was then that the players found out the actual timeline of this bug. It was initially found six months earlier.

This, is a true story.

reviewText:
Although all the cons, I'm still recommending this game. It is simply fun. If you do not have high expectations, just wish to spend some time it is your game.


Pros:
- Well it is fun. The quests are narrated, and have real stories. Also you can find lots of lore objects to know more about the world.
- Looks nice.
- Almost all of the tools / interfaces are reachable from Browser.
- Have a minigame with dice-rolling, from browser, if you have 5-10 mins during the day. The minigame can yield in useful items. (I have not told it will be quick, as the Tier6 dungeons are really hard - like collect 18 shield from 8 dice...)
- Have some connections with the original Neverwinter games.


Cons:
- It is not D&D.
- Still bugging after almost 1 year, eg: many times the daily quests cannot be completed.
- Lagging, in dungeons the latency usually fine, but around peak hours it is (or at least feels like) more than a second, and with the dodging system, it is sometimes lethal.
- Graphics of the game is nice, but clattering. It would really need some optimalization
- The PvE part is fun, till lv 55 and after it became hard, and turning to a pay to win game.
- The PVP part is still under development, some pvp is available, but the single map became boring after a while.
- Items has variety of looks, although the same item looks the same on all of the races. At least as dwarf, I have not seen any difference from sun elf, or from humans.
- To gather the real" money

reviewText:
I've changed this review several times. The game gets good, the game gets bad, and then it gets mediocre again.

But this time they can't bring me back, and I know for a fact that they have lost many other loyal fans.

With the addition of Module 6, Elemental Evil, came the realization that the developers behind this game care nothing for it, and only care to fill Cryptic's wallets.

They do not develop the game. They develop a business, and a shoddy one at that.

With this most recent module came a level cap increase. This increase was very poorly integrated, both from a chronological standpoint as well as a financial standpoint. It was released only a few months after the Rise of Tiamat" campaign
date:
which introduced the game's first set of Legendary "Artifact" weapons and armor.

These were made obsolete by the raise in level cap.

Also integrated were several new maps
recommended: which proved equally as useless and buggy. They were essentially re-lit versions of maps from old campaigns. Mind you
hoursPlayed: Module 6 was postponed a whole month from it's original date; for what? Exceedingly subpar

column20: they can remove items from packs
column21: change them from being bound to account to being bind on equip or bind on pickup
column22: and not even change the item's description in doing so. And you can do nothing about it.\n\nThey fired their old dev after Mod 6's release
column23: hired a new one
column24: and he immediately promised to "fix the game." He hardly acknowledged many of the most prominant complaints
column25:
and in his first hotpatch made the purchasable bags "Bind on Equip" from "Bound to Account."

A community moderator from their forums gave me an interesting quote to work with:

reviewText: I used to love this game, I even wrote a very positive review on it. And it is good! controls are perfect, runs fine, graphics are good, combat is good. You can't work hard to get over powered, as for grinding and completeing hard quests doesn't do ♥♥♥♥ compared to buying zen. you could literally be playing for ♥♥♥♥ing eternity, grinding and getting everything you can get and still be eclipsed by some kid with a credit card and an hour of gameplay. reviewText:
Used to be fun.  Ignore my hrs recorded here on Steam as I usually play via ARC and only use this to play the game when ARC is going crazy and won't let me log in. It used to have a free to play model and in some ways, it still is.  However, they  (as of this writing) have sneakily reinserted a subscription perk called a VIP program that makes it pay to win as the perks listed definitely brings a major advantage against most non-subs.

Also, as of this writing, there's some tomfoolery going on during high level dungeons crawls on pugs that gets you kicked out via teammates that want the loot for themselves or for their friends that weren't even in the group.  I started playing around February of 2015 and got almost all of my toons of every class and race not hidden behind a pay wall to max level, but the grind for gear on dungeons for the newly max level character almost stops due to other players kicking you out of the group for the abovementioned reason in regards to loot.   After experiencing it more than once soured my overall experience of the game.

Pros: fun levelling, impressive graphics, some of the quests are downright hilarious in terms of story/spoken dialogue.

Cons: See my rant above.

Conclusion:  If you can stand the cons, then you'll enjoy the game.   It could have been a WOW killer... unfortunately, that potential got wasted.

reviewText: I actually liked this game for a while but eventually it got really old fast. Same old quests where you kill this amount of mobs and find a certain amount of these, but thats not the worst part in it. I hated the end game ♥♥♥♥ where you had to only do one quest a day. It actually makes you wait 24 hours before you can do another. With the sheer amount of end game content itsw not worth it. I figured out that it would take more than a year to actually beat it, and by then they would have already come out with even more end game content for you to wait on. Then again you could spendd hundreds of dollars just so that you can beat it. Yeah this game is a p2w, dont believe anyone that says its not. You have to pay for everything, mounts, gear, in game money, and even for your own guild you have to pay. I spent only 5 dollars in it and that was to get some in game cash and I didnt get ♥♥♥♥ for it, all I got was a common mount that anyone else could get. For people playing it now I would suggest leaving now before the devs make it any worse than it is.

reviewText:
The gameplay is a ton of fun.  Very action oriented, no tab-targeting, no 3-bars of twelve buttons to keybind/naga map, etc..

The game is NOT P2win, cash shop is just faster mounts, better companions, and the traditional stuff like more bag slots.  Yeah, the stuff is expensive but you don't have to unlock every race, unlock every mount (you can only ride one at a time) to have fun, and get every companion.  You can still play 9 of the 12 races for free.

I don't think I put money into this game until playing it for 50-hours.  And I've paid $50+ dollars for MANY games that I've played less than 10-hours.  It is either fun or it is not, and this game is fun.

reviewText:
I started playing this game out of boredom and found quite a few hours to do the starting quests, up to level 60.
Since I am no classic MMORPG player, my review is mainly based on my experiences in that game without direct comparison to any of the other billion MMORPGs out there.

Lets start with variety:
You have to choose a certain race and role on the beginning. Each role has it's own abilities. Depending on what skills you use later on, you can fulfill multiple purposes in each role.
The game is quite interesting on start and it's fun to try out new abilities as you level up and get your first horse or companion. At least on start you get the impression of following some sort of storyline, doing several different things. After a while it gets very repetitive since quests quickly change to a pure seek and destroy.
Finishing the first plot"
date: you will be sent to the capital city to a certain officer that offers new quests which allow you to visit other places.\nMost places are fairly nice to look at (depending on your settings) and the level design is pretty interesting in several cases. You get to fight a variety of enemies
recommended:
a few of which have specilized abilities as you progress into higher levels.

Second point would be fighting and the skilling tree:
Fighting requires some concentration as strong enemie's attacks are displayed on the ground as a warning. These warnings and some slow mob's attacks are supposed to be dodged by running away or staying out of range.
The skill tree offers a variety of different spells and abilities. These are divided into:
-"daily powers"
hoursPlayed: which supposed to be strong spells and need action points to be filled up
voteText: likely through fighting.\n-"free powers"
helpfulPercent: which are started using the left and right mouse button and can be seen as a variety of basic attacking techniques.\n-(red powers?) ...are what you would call a spell. Cooldowns
votesHelpful: damage values and/or custom effects.\n\nIn addition
votesTotal:
you get a variety of so-called "talents" that start with basic ones and advance into specialized talents that would power certains aspects of your normal abilities.
Experimenting with these to find your own playstyle is interesting.

So much for the major gameplay. Now off to the (many) points why I wouldn't recommend playing this game at it's current stage:

My main point would be the lack of originality and heartblood.
Everything you get to do has already been there many many times in countless other MMORPGs. After a nice start
votesFunny: the game quickly breaks down into loveless quest design and the further you go
commentsCount: the more confused you get.\nA constant flood of items without any sort of explanation about the point to it fills the inventory. Every time you figured out what to do with one of those strange new coins you found
column16: the game is telling you to collect another 2 kinds of coins. The sheer amount of different "currencies" is nuts
column17:
while the majority of these will be outdated by the time you figured out what they are for.
Huge areas with different questing points of any kind of importance spread all over make it very hard if not impossible to orientate on which plot you are actually working right now and where you may want to get something special from.

The progress after the first levels is very quickly nullified and the game wants you to spend many hours on tiny steps forward. If you want to use the things you find
column18: you are supposed to collect immense amounts of points in certain "currencies" the further your level progresses. The game very quickly yells at you "BUY OUR STUFF OR YOU WON'T GET ANYWHERE".\nIt may be free to play
column19: but it's very close to "pay to progress".\n\nAs soon as you get to fight in a group
column20: you quickly lose track of what's going on. Insane amounts of special effects from the players
column21: their companions and the minions often make it a lag fest where you see nothing anymore and steer on your cooldowns to use the next spell on the "blazing-green-red-white-yellow-blue" part of your screen where you saw a dragon a few minutes ago
column22:
hoping he's still there.

Going over to the serverside:
Terrible server performance and countless bugs make playing a mess quite often. Constantly brought out new content keeps flooding the already messed up system. Reported bugs do not seem to be worked on in time - if at all.


Since the content of this game is too huge to break down most things
column23: I tried to keep it at a minimum. There are many more things I didn't like about this game. Unless there are major changes (keyword is major)
column24: I cannot recommend playing this game."

reviewText:
I started writing a detailed review and just couldn't be bothered

It's a great MMO until you reach level 70 and then you'll realize that this game has no End Game content, No armor set variations, little to no character skill variation, a beyond imbalanced pvp system with a whole 2 types of pvp game and a complete lack of anything to do or work towards.

The Strongholds mod was supposed to breath new life into the game but what it ended up doing was giving people a place to go stand around that wasn't the main city.

Imagine watching Rocky for the first time except in the final fight Rocky knocks Apollo out with the first punch and we all just sit there for the last 20 minutes watching Rocky wander around the ring looking for something to do

Thats how this game made me feel. Pretty good at the start and the middle then flopped on it's face when it came to the end.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nThis is a fun game from lvls 1-60. Once you reach 60, it takes forever to lvl up and you are motivated by epic dungeons, which become available at lv 70. At lvl 70 the game goes from being free to play to free to lose. If you do not spend real money it is almost impossible to get decent gear or be able to afford to upgrade gear. You have a limit of about 36k rough AD you can refine per day, so that is your limit on income you can earn without paying. You can earn AD through other means, such as exploiting the constantly buggy auction house, or selling the items you get from dungeons, this still pays very low and consumes tons of time. If you do decide to play the game and put up with all the bugs, it is helpful to get VIP, which at the moment costs about 495k AD using the AD exchange. This will take a lot of time if you do not use real money, but it gives you and enchantment key and after having it for two months, I pretty much make the money I paid for it back, but haven't made more. Do not buy enchantment keys, they are a rip off and you will lose a lot of AD most of the time. It is a lot about luck, it is possible to buy 20 keys and get a legendary item, but most likely you will open 20 boxes and all average items and a few epics that still do not make up for the price of the keys. I have opened over a 100 boxes and have never gotten a legendary item. I have heard of people who have played for 8 months with VIP and got one, so it can happen. Just be aware it is very unlikely. I would recommend not spending any money on this game because the exchange rate is horrible and it is not a good game to invest in. It gets old and boring very fast once you understand how long it will take you to earn enough for good items. Rate: 6/10

reviewText:
Stay far away from this game, if you're new to it. Your wallet (and sanity) will thank me later.

Many MMORPGs fail to consider their new blood, but this is easily one of the most egregious offenders you can find on Steam as a whole. It's a blight on gaming in general, an abject lesson in taking a once-great title and driving it straight into the ground over money. There's no balance of time versus money. You will pay up on this one, or you won't be competitive.

The PvE content is only truly fun up till 60 (when they introduce the horrible Mod 6 content -- and it just gets worse from there on in terms of agonisingly boring grinding), and PvP is for masochists only. Mobs will regularly one or two shot you in epic dungeons, and established players are invincible in the battlegrounds... assuming you can find a PvP match at all, with the game's lengthy queues. This developer has chased their players away, and for good reason.

reviewText: This game has the absolute worst customer service I have ever encountered. During a break, my account was hacked and millions of AD worth of items were stolen. When I contacted customer service I was asked for some account information which I gave, and finally, after a week and a half and one single response from Perfect World per day (regardless of how quickly I responded to their emails), was told they could not restore my account. I was upset and asked for a refund on a Zen purchase I had made during the time of the ticket being open. This request was also declined. At this point I am absolutely furious. I was a VIP subscriber and had spent a generous amount of money on Zen in the last few years. Do not make the same mistakes I have, do not give Perfect World your money, they will completely disappoint and disregard you.

reviewText:
I first picked this game up when it was released. My initial impression was good. A Free to Play that seemed to allow players to advance without spending real money, albeit  a bit slower than paying players, is acceptable. The combat system is not quite what I was expecting from a D&D title (cooldown based abilities all around), but it is still a LOT of fun. Very easy, quick controls that respond well, as long as the server is not lagging (which, unfortunately, happens a LOT). But I still played it, and had a lot of fun doing so. I spent a little money on it, just so I could open some of those lockboxes, and I did manage to get an epic sword and cloak out of them.

This was a couple of years ago, though, before the changes that recently hit. Since then, they have taken this game from a Free-to-Play to an all out money grab. It has gone from Free-to-Play, to Pay-to-Win.

-AD rewards have been nerfed. No way to acquire the currency needed to buy things from the auction house unless you buy something from the Zen market first.
-The zone dungeons are broken (literally removed from the game, for reasons I will speculate on later).
-We now have at least 3 types of those infernal, blasted, annoying, inventory-slot-robbing lockboxes that can only be opened with a key that can only be acquired through the Zen market. I have only seen 3 types; there are likely more, and they drop CONSTANTLY. You WILL get them, even when you don't want them. There are constant system messages pasting across the screen, stating things like,So-and-so just got an epic whats-it-ma-thingy-with-flames-flying-from-its-rump from a Rusted
recommended: yet somehow still shows EPIC rarity lockbox of money grabbing."\n-Loot drops
hoursPlayed: which were never all that great
voteText: are now an abysmal joke. I consistently see the same 2 or 3 pieces of armor dropping in every single zone.\n-Quest rewards are a waste
helpfulPercent: if not an outright insult. Remember when I said the dungeons were removed? Yeah
votesHelpful: those used to be the only source of decent gear in the game that didn't require you to open your wallet. They're gone now
votesTotal: but the devs left the quest links and markers in place.\n\nI saw all these changes
votesFunny: and I decided to conduct an experiment. I bought $50.00 worth of Zen and bought as many keys as I could. I think I ended up with thirty of them
commentsCount: making each one cost about $1.60. I had some Zen left over

column17: do ALL of these games have pricing schemes that make it impossible to take your "currency" balance to zero?). Anyway

column20: and a 5th character slot for buying stuff on the Zen market. 50 bucks got me NOTHING worth mentioning. No epic gear

and a modest amount of astral diamonds.

Pathetic.

I could go on

This game was pretty good when I first played it. But I guess there was something I was overlooking when I first played it as well that basically is the worst thing ever.

This game is a cash grab. Just look at the price of the DLCs and that says enough. See all those people running around on cool mounts? Gotta buy em, otherwise your stuck with a plain Jane horse. Companions? Money. Crafting? Money, Items? Money. Dungeons? Money. Money Money Money. Everything in this game has a price tag and while the in game prices aren't too bad, that's where they hook you. ♥♥♥♥ is cheap and odds are you'll get Something" of use out of each random bag you buy meaning you'll keep spending gobs of money. reviewText:
Game is an insult to The Forgotten Realms franchise and a slap in the face to it's creator Ed Greenwood, if your expecting an Advanced Dungeons & Dragons experience you'd have a better chance at Dungeons & Dragons Online.

~ Numerous issues listed below:

- Performs substandard no matter what build your desktop is (and I'm running off a i7 Quad Core @ 4.4Ghz and two SLi'd GTX 780s with 16gb DDR Corsair Veng Ram and this game runs like a slug)

- Game is overpopulated with gold spammers and the community devs do nothing to address the issue at hand

- Game is Pay to Win - cannot access better companions unless you pay an absurd amount of money basic blue quality one is 29.99$ USD

- Combat is Clunky at best more like Two Worlds when it was first launched; complete inbalances with classes

- Contradictions involving Lore if you've read any of the Lore Books or The Forgotten Realms Campaign Booklet

- Magic System is mediocre heavily favors melee characters over spellcasters (not unforeseen as most MMO companies seem to have some unrestrained hatred towards anything that doesnt swing a giant metal stick); game contains 4% of the spells in PhB, devs add their own versions of spells which contradict pre-existing spells.

- Alignment System forces you to play Good/Lawful or Neutral no option or flexibility to be Chaotic or Lawful Evil or Neutral Evil (completely biased against anyone who wants to play the greedy backstabbing merc or someone who wants to dabble in Necromancy)

- Servers latency is worse than a 64k Dial Up Modem, constant disconnects.

- Uses the Awesimium Process which is considered spyware to monitor your computer (possibility it's recording http sites you are visiting so it can spam your registered email with junk mail later)

- Character Proportions completely wrong; Tiefling look like full Daemons unlike what they look in AD&D of a mix of human and Daemon depending on the Generation the Tiefling is.

- Limited Imagination of the Dev Team and Imperfect World" as me and my friends call them.

- Little to no Customer Support; never address the issue with all of their games it has taken 1 year 3 months for them to get the mailing system somewat function again in STO; many quest markers have issues such as bugging or not working properly

All In All horrible game to play not worth the time or effort invested.

((I dont play through Steam I played through their PW client))"

reviewText: After playing my heart out of Neverwinter Nights 2 in my teen years, I came upon this game with nostalgia induced passion. Only to realize this is the age of Pay-to-Win gaming. A factor I found that hurt the core of the games that utilized this. Neverwinter Nights 2 may have been an old game, and I still play it now, but I cannot bring myself to hit the thumbs up" on this game. I have never liked an RPG based game that did not enforce actual Roleplaying
recommended: and whose active community was unwelcoming.\n\nI don't mean to say this is a bad game
hoursPlayed: it's got a few great features
voteText:
such as:
- Graphical abilities
- Great Camera Angling
- The ability to actually jump.
- Utilizes D&D 4.0 guidelines
- Interesting progression rates
- Great HUD
- Free to play

But here were the exact areas I felt hurt the actual gameplay:
- Pay-to-Win
- Non-enforced RolePlay in a RolePlaying Game & Server (players talking OOC all the time)
- Unwelcoming community
- Leveling up granted no satisfaction in creating your character
- In-ability to crossclass

Though personally I would rather play D&D 3.5"

reviewText:
They ruined the Dungeons and Dragons franchise when they made a F2P P2W MMO, the game itself is fun untill you come across the glaring gear disparity between those who pay and those who don't.

The ability to make up quests and stuff like that gives this game a ton of content much like the earlier Neverwinter games, the pvp is entertaining - hardly balanced but that's neither here nor there, it's still fun but again is ruined by this P2W model.

It really is a shame as this game is actually quite playable in terms of functionality controls and having an interesting environment not to mentions the ♥♥♥♥♥on of lore they can draw from.

This games worth a playthrough if you're really bored with other MMOs but by no means worth sticking around with the P2W attitude to end game.

If they had offered Neverwinter as a once off payment of about $80 with none of the P2W options ingame this would have been great. They even could have charged again for expansions.

P2W is honestly the worst thing i've ever seen in online gaming, it completely defeats the purpose of gaming in a competitive environment and Neverwinter 100% subscribes to this model.

reviewText:
Lost in translation between an MMO and the pen and paper source material, Cryptic studios has birthed a tepid monstrosity of classic dungeons and dragons.  In lieu of a glorious celebration of problem solving, fierce combat, and character interactions, we're given a series of adventures so generic that it brings up comparisons to decades prior.  Game mechanics similarly suffer a compromise between core dungeons and dragons concepts from fourth edition, and traditional MMO fair.  While it isn't necessarily terrible, especially for a free game, it doesn't warrant our attention either, and I'm stuck wondering who it appeals to.

Forgotten Realms beckons adventures to sally forth to the wonderful locales such as Neverwinter, Icewind Dale, and other notable cities to defeat the evil Lich Queen Valindra as she does what all evil characters do; bring about death and destruction.  Story wise, it's so by the numbers that about an hour into it I was just clicking to get my quests.  The game throws so many tropes at you that it defies belief; a person you just met dying while trying to ingratiate himself to you, a fetch quest belaying the importance of resources to soldiers, and so forth.  There was even a quest to save three privates from becoming zombies, and after it was finished I wasn't allowed to save any more, dredging up memories of the infamous dickwolves strip of penny arcade.  These things aren't necessarily bad, as tropes can be used very effectively, but these are just sloppy.

Continuing in much the same fashion, we're told that opportunists are wreaking havok on the land of Neverwinter, and we're tasked with helping out.  Only, I really didn't want to, because most of the people we're saving are ♥♥♥♥♥.  I understand that conceptually, a MMO demands effort on the behalf of a player to reach rewards like enough money to buy weapons and armor.  When a city is in direct peril, and the fate of shopkeepers ultimately depends on me killing five zombies or collecting three leafs, fleecing me an arm and a leg to get a shield that will increase my odds of survival, or treating me like an a-hole isn't really motivation enough to get on my high horse to defeat the arch bad guy, or save the crown jewel from Nashkel, or even delivering a message to Sargent Whatshisname.

Clearly, it doesn't take any chances on bucking the formula with the narrative, and largely it plays it safe with the game play as well.  After playing for a couple of hours, I can see that the team took ques from fourth edition, but the concepts don't really apply to an MMO.  Having encounters, daily's, and at wills stressed cooperation with your team and planning for the next encounter in the pen and paper version.  Here it means waiting a bit to mash e or q.  A cheap cop out for an MMO, timing is only a small part of it.  Your life is now preposterously high to compensate for a lack of a traditional AC system.  There aren't many choices to customize your character beyond putting points in different powers to level them up.  Purchasable/findable kits allow players to bypass certain skill blocks like thievery or dungeoneering, and all for the sake of looting, nothing more.  Essentially, it negates the importance of player choice, and emphasizes purchase power.

Perfectly exemplifying the translation from pen and paper to MMO would be the previous Dungeons and Dragons Online.  Where it succeeds, and likewise Neverwinter fails, is letting the player define their character in so many ways.  Not just in play style or character creation, but also letting the character choose how they interact with the NPC's, solve quests, and align themselves with the different factions.  The questing itself was extremely varied, and conjured amazing stories, like a drinking contest with beholders, or a carnival of the undead.  It was an amazing triumph that empowered the player to adventure and discover, not just run between quest giver and questing zone.  Here, there is very little the player has an affect on, which makes it feel soulless.

I've spent little time with Neverwinter, so I can only hope that it improves beyond the initial image it conveys.  Reading more about the game though, I'm struck with my impression of tedium and depression.  We've all been “the chosen one” who can destroy the great evil and bring peace to the land, but rarely are we impressed enough to continue that adventure to its climax.  Neverwinter is an adventure for a different kind of player, and sadly it isn't the one Dungeons and Dragons traditionally appeals to.  If you're looking for an MMO fix, you can do far worse, and it isn't necessarily a terrible game in its own right.  It is uninspired, and in a market with far better choices, I can't justify spending any more time in the Forgotten Realms.

reviewText:
This game is not terrible, but it's not very good either. I love Cryptic games, especially the engine in which these games run. Both Champions Online and Star Trek Online are controller compatible. Why was that feature removed from Neverwinter I'll never understand. But let's ignore that for a second, I'm not a D&D fan so the lack of accurate lore other people complain about doesn't affect this review, I'm going to base it off gameplay, fun factor and economy.

Let's start with gampley, this is a hybrid action MMO. You can move around and even avoid some attacks by moving but when you attack you're locked in place. Once you get used to that then the gameplay shouldn't be a problem. Except when we go and look at your efficiency in battle. Your level ups grant you attribute points to make the build that best fit your style, OK that's normal. But then we have gear and that's when things get out of control. You have a variety of ways to get the right gear for your build:

1. Be on an efficient and active Guild willing to baby sit you while you farm it (good luck with that )
2. Farm the currency you need to convert into gear. (I'll talk about the economy in a bit)
3. Buy the currency to get the top gear (better known as Pay 2 Win)

Which brings us to the economy

Astral Diamonds is the top currency. You use it for almost EVERYTHING and you have a daily cap (to refine it) of 24,000 (if I'm not mistaken) Want to level up your mount? OK that's a couple of million astrals per level. Want to level your companion, Another couple of million of astrals. Plenty of things you want to buy you need astrals for, and even to transmute some gear. The entire auction house uses astrals as currency, so that armor that some dude was lucky enough to land on a dungeon run, well you may have to pay close to a million 'cause people aren't selling things for cheap. So that's farming Astral Events (skirmish) which take anything from 5-30 minutes (depending on the team and your level) for 1,000AD each run, Doing daily missions (which can take a very long time as some involve running the same instance multiple times in a row to complete and pretty sure the best one pays only 8,000 AD and that's unlocked at lvl 60) So basically you'll spent most of the day, every day trying to hit the refinement cap so you can get enough astrals to buy ONE piece of gear you want. Yes you can sell your stuff for astrals and those are already refined, but that means you'll have to spend hours farming good enough stuff to sell and hope to god someone has the money" to buy it. Even worse if you want to level your companions

reviewText:
I cannot blindly recommend this game without knowing what the potential player is looking for.  The game doesn't appear to be very deep regarding NwN/D&D lore, so if that's what you're looking for I'd think purchasing a copy of Neverwinter Nights or Neverwinter Nights 2 a good idea and seeking out a player run persistent server.

If you're looking for a game with a good combat engine, and some pretty fun multiplayer (with friends) then i can see this game being a good fit, especially considering The Foundry and the idea of playing player made content (which i have yet to experience but read its quite good). On the other hand it does seem to be buggy and laggy in high populated areas, and if you're into MMO PvP, stay away.  Just looking at whats in the in-game-store, its quite obvious this game is pay to win.

There is also some weird issue with censorship on the Perfect World forums (Chinese policed internet?).

All in all, id only recommend if you have some friends to group with, and are not looking for anything to deep or involving.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game and put in some time to give the game a chance.  Much like other reviews have stated, you are slapped in the face with so many pay walls.  So, I gave in, bought some Zen and did so because there was a bonus program.  My purchase met the requirements for the bonus.  Or so I thought.  Because I made my purchase on Steam, I was not eligable for the bonus.  However, this was not stated anywhere in game, nor was I warned during the purchase.  I found this out after using their ticket system and experienceing their poor customer service.

So, my reasons for not recommending this are:

- Too many pay walls.
- Bait and switch on the Zen purchases via Steam.
- Poor customer service.
- Builds are very limited.
- Not all that challenging and somewhat boring.

reviewText:
While Neverwinter isn't quite pay to win, it wouln't be a stretch to call it pay-to-enjoy. The monitization strategy PW chose for the game is to place all sorts of artifical obstiicles and inconveniences in the game, which can of course be trivially overcome if you just spend money, and they choose to remind you of that with the hard sell at every possible turn.

Customer service is terrible, even for paying customers, with support tickets taking days to be resolved,

Long standing bugs and balance issues abound, with developers not even paying lip service to addressing them.

All in all, these factors combine to turn what could otherwise be an amazing expreience into an absolute slum of a MMO.
Save your time and money for a game that respects both.

reviewText:
It's hard to not recommend a game when you supported it through closed beta. It's fun for awhile but, IMO, the trick to making money in a F2P model is to not constantly force it in the player's face. I wouldn't say it's pay-to-win, and you could enjoy the game without spending a dime if you are ok with three big negatives. 1.) It's not D&D; 2.) It's nowhere close to being an expansion of the Forgotten Realms games; 3.) You will constantly be reminded that you can spend real money. That said, I did enjoy the dungeon-building. (I didn't build one, but I enjoyed playing others' campaigns.) It's worth playing around with for awhile but the revenue model takes away from a lot of the fun.

*** EDIT

I agree with Random Gamer in that Neverwinter is not P2W. This is a case where I really wish that Steam offered a continuum rather than a binary Yes/No range of recommendation options. Of my three complaints, the only one that drove the thumbs-down was the amount of in-game promotion of, even if not necessarily the case, what appeared to be driving one to a cash shop".

That said
date: I admit that this sentiment is based on my experiences immediately into launch. Developers adapt and adopt different strategies for generating the income that they justifiably need and deserve; therefore

reviewText: Neverwinter is free-to-play, and we’ll get a bit more into pay-to-win, pay-for-convenience elements later.  The important thing here is players can get right into the game and begin playing without friction.Neverwinter boasts one of the best combat systems in any MMORPG on the market today.  It’s not the bogged down tab-target “sit-and-watch, hit 1 2 3” that the genre grew up with, nor has the pendulum swung all the way toward the oft touted “action-MMORPG”Every class in Neverwinter can solo quite easily, and because the combat is probably the game’s greatest strength, there’s no shortage of fun for those electing solitary confinement.

reviewText:
(This review deals exclusively with Neverwinter's Dungeon Creator and its community)

I sunk dozens of hours (all before Neverwinter was on Steam) into the one redeeming quality of this game: the level editor. It's one of the best I've ever seen and writing, planning, and creating dungeons and quests is an awesome game in itself. I can't say enough in its praise.

However, even this element of the game is ruined by the toxic community. Creators band together in level-making mafias to promote and upvote each others' dungeons (without letting on that they all in it together), and God forbid you ever give less than a 4/5 to one their quests--they will downvote your creations in retaliation.

That this game's playerbase can take something wonderful like the dungeon creator and infuse with all the nastiness and spite of hardcore PvP left such a bitter taste in my mouth that I've never touched the game again.

reviewText:
While not the best, it's one of the best f2p games that you have to try.

The goodLovely graphics.
Full voice acting quests. Quests are also good and most are interesting too.
Unique approach. At times it feels more of an arpg with a community hub, than an mmo.
Enjoyable events.
Foundry!! I find foundry to be one of the best things happened to gaming in recent years, no overreacting here. You can have an endless source of quests, dungeons and adventures, all made from users. I hope other games will follow this example. The meh/badWhile it's not pay2win, it does need a big amount of time playing to get basic upgrades.
It's not very hard. While plays normal for an arpg, it does feel easy and doable for an mmorpg.I've invested more than 160 hours and i can say i got back a nice and at times, unforgettable experience. It's not your average mmo as it tries to mix many things together, but the result is nice and it does its job done. It offers a nice gaming time in a beautiful crafted world. Try it, after all it's free.

8,5/10

It looks a lovely game but beware the firm's tech support. I've just tried to play a new character, but their server failed mid-game. reviewText:
8.4/10 - One of the Better FREEish Multiplayer Games

This game is pretty sweet; the graphics are great and the world has a magical essence that I do love. The cities and maps in general really brought me to this game and didn't disappoint! The combat is really fluid and allows you to take a more active role as opposed to some MMOs that have a more turn based style of fighting. Quests are voice acted and pretty fun for the most part if not repetitive.

While this game isn't World of Warcraft or even Rift (in my opinion); it has a lot to offer for FREE. If you love to level cap and do the PVP thing then this really isn't the game for you! You will have to pay real money to grab the gear to make this possible.

If you are like me and just really enjoy games like WOW, and don't currently want to spend $15/mo; then this will be a good one for you.

It's FREE; so you should give it a go!

reviewText: Always on the lookout for a great F2P game, and this one sure stands up. Yeah there are the WoW-geeks and stat-trads that like to gear score themselves out of any fun in MMRPG universe, but there is something for everyone here - especially D&D fans. Take the time to explore and appreciate the level designs, you will not regret it. Itis regularly updated for content and has its share of seasonal events and goodies. There is relatively little frustration with levelling (not really sure why power-levelling scabs / Astral gem / gold farming hax even bother, but even the laziest of lazy like to play games too I suppose). Levels can mostly be done solo or with a companion, but in the tradition of D&D, try to form a party or get your friends to play with you - way more fun! Overall very fun, gorgeous graphics and within the spirit of the venerable game.

reviewText:
After playing this game for 17 hours or so and reaching level 22 on a Human Great Weapon Fighter class I say that this game is pretty good for a free to play MMO. I am pleasantly surprised how Perfect World Entertainment did with the D&D game.

Aside from the questing and lore in the game (there is lots of D&D lore) the Enchanting and upgrading enchanting is done nicely and there is lots of Enchanted Chest drops.

The queue system for daily's and groups is nice to see. I hate when a new MMO is released without the basic options to make playing fun.

The Foundry" (opens up to you at level 15) lets you create user based content and quests. There is plenty of daily quests to do and Dungeon Delves where you get some nice piece of loot when the time comes up for these options.

Down Side I don't like is that to open the enchanted lock box's you need an enchanted key and that can only be bought on the market place and you need to use Zen to buy on the in game store."

reviewText:
I'll keep this short, since all I really wanted to do is drop off a thumbs down.

Pretty  much everything that people say about mod 6 is true. The grindfest for the endgame is already unbearable if you are an old-timer (like me) with 10 characters as profession farms. If you just started the game you will rue the day you hit lvl 65-70, unless you have a few hundred $$ to spare on this game.

Prior to endgame the content is actually still fun, (as long as you avoid pvp), especially if you level through foundry quests. Don't get serious with this game until they fix the mess of mod 6 though.

Edit: Ever since cryptic changed the AD economy things have gotten a wee bit better, if you are a casual player. The grindfest that is level 68 however still remains, and the refining systems to upgrade your gear is so painfully slow and expensive that you can spend more than half a year on one character's minute upgrades, while you repeat the same dungeons and daily quests, day after day.

reviewText:
I haven't played this game for too long, but what i saw did not impress me. Let me point out why it didn't.

1. Graphics: I don't have that good of a computer, which sucks. With newer mmorpgs, i have to turn it to low to avoid lag. In this, not only was it horrible looking on low, it lagged quite a bit. AA looked and ran better. So in short, the graphics are dependent on your pc. For me, they were horrible, with heavily pixilated details when they appeared.

2. Gameplay: Now, this is the main reason I played the game for more than an hour. You have a smaller hotbar of skills, making you think about what skills you will pick. I played the Guardian guy, and the combat was solid. It was similar to Tera in you don't just click and target, you do each slash individually. And if you play the class I did, you can actually block with your shield, which is small byt refreshing. You also have this ultimate skill which is pretty cool. Overall, ifound the combat fun. reviewText:
I purchased this thinking that Dragon Born would have the option to select Bahamut as a diety and that there would be some unique dialogue and/or content associated with the various Dragon Born NPCs around the Faerun world.  I was, sorely, disappointed.  All of the Dragon Born NPCs treat you as if you are just another adventurer instead of one of their own.  Cryptic was lazy and did not create any helmet art other than the 2 pieces that come in the pack.  One is for a ceremonial fashion set and the other simple overlapping plates on the head.  The 'toon' looks ridiculous on a horse, so if you are one those who wants your character to look cool, you will have to buy (with real money) a larger mount.  To get the Metalic Dragon skins, you will have to gamble your way thru lockboxes, that are only available for Astral Diamonds, and buy however many keys (about $1.25 each) it takes to get it.

The other content is okay.  The bag helps to keep from having to find a vendor all the time, The Heart of the Red dragon artifact helps at low levels and the ring is okay.  The rest of it is just fluff.  You can't even use the overloads until you reach 60th level and then only in special sets of armor you have to grind your way to get.

Not worth $75.  Not even worth the $60 I paid for it while it was on sale.  If you just have to have the dragon born race, spend the $25 to get a race reroll token (less if you get an in-game coupon for 15% off any zen market item).  The race reroll token can be use, after creating a regular character, to reroll it as a dragon born.

reviewText:
Neverwinter might have been a interesting light MMO but greed has destroyed the game.

The current policy in the game is to maximize profits at the exclusion of everything else. To that end nearly all development time is devoted to make more sellable items. The many bugs in the game, even the game breaking ones like dungeon chests always giving the same loot, go unaddressed for a long time. Exploits have destroyed the economy and using them has gone unpunished meaning that especially as new player you will be faced with prices you won't be able to pay even for simple items.
But as that means that some people might buy Zen for real money this was not addressed by Cryptic at all.

The prices of all items you can buy with real money are just laughable. $70 for a badly made race (they do not even have helmet textures) or $50 for skipping content (which is mind numbingly boring like all campaigns cryptic does but give permanent bonuses). To hide the true cost items can only rarely be bought separatly and are instead bundled together with lots of useless stuff. Cryptic is also not above using fake sales like selling the Dragonborn pack for $75 for a limited time instead of $100, but after the sale" ends they change the normal price to $75.

To keep players in line the official forums are patrolled heavily by mods and any mentioning of problems in the game will get the post deleted and you might also get banned. This includes warnings others about mislabeled "Bind on Equip" items which are instead "Bind on Pickup" (the current bug that shall not be named).

And finally Steam users are constantly harrased in the game as Cryptic wants to push their ARC launcher instead of steam. That means when you buy something through steam you are on probation for several weeks and face severe restrictions until Cryptic verifies that your money is good. And redeeming keys is only possible with the ARC launcher and not through a website.

Stay away from the game
date: the greedy practices of Cryptic and the neglect of actual issues is sucking all potential fun out of it."

reviewText: Pay to win.

reviewText:
Pros: The combat in the game is really fun, its not your tipical click and wait MMO. It feels more like an action adventure game, where position and dodging is key to survive.

Cons: A) BUUUUUUGSSSSSSS: The game was launched as a full game on june 2013, so you´ll think the game is in a playable state, yet the VERY FIRST DUNGEON in the game was bugged and to my knowledge to this day its still bugged and it cant be completed and the fourt dungeon you can access was also bugged and couldnt be completed. I understand that MMO may have bugs and glitches after release, but after a year, having your VERY FIRST DUNGEON IN THE GAME BUGGED IS UNACCEPTABLE....also crashes, falling through the map, dungeon bosses who wont drop any loot, etc

B) The time you spend leveling from 1 to 60 is the most repetitive process i have ever seen in an mmo. You start in a city, you get a quest to teleport to a certain area, you go there, accept a bunch of quest that involve either killing X amount of enemies or gather X amount of materials, you complete them and then you get 1 more quest that asks you to go to a unique instance and fight a mini boss, you go back to the quest giver who tells you to go to a different quest giver in a different part of the area, once you get there is the same thing...5 to 7 quest and then a miniboss, you do this 3 times before you are sent back to the city to go to a different area....AND THIS HAPPENS IN EVERY AREA, 5-7 quest, mini boss, do this 3 times and you are done with that area

C) Even though you can be a f2p without a problem, from lvl 1 to 60, everything in the game is hiden behind a paywall. Like any other MMO by perfect world enterteinment, the game has 3 different kinds of currency

1)Bronze, silver and gold coins: Classic mmo currency, that is basically useless, since the things you can buy with it are limited to potions, 1 single mount (a horse that comes in 6 differnet colors) and very low lvl gear.

2)Astral diamonds: Unique currency in the game that can be obtained by doing daily quest or by doing certain profession tasks. This is the most usefull currency in the game and so the hardest to get. You can use it to buy high lvl gear (you can pretty much avoid the dungeon grinding for gear at lvl 60 and buy a whole set of gear using diamonds) The auction house items can ONLY be bought with astral diamonds, unique mounts, cosmetics, basically everything that you cant buy with the previous currency must be bought with astral diamonds, especially the most important item in the game...the scroll of identification, that are used to idenfity gear so you can see the stats and wear it and since enemies have a higher chance of dropping gear than scrolls you are going to end up with a bag full of green or blue items that you cant wear because you dont have scrolls.

3) Zen: The universal currency of everysingle perfect world entertainment game, can only be bought with real-life money and you can use it to buy more astral daimonds or other items like keys used to open lockboxes or the most basic feature of every mmo out there...resseting your character stats in case you made a mistake, yep, you can only respec" your character if you pay real money...thankfully there is an in-game feature that allows real players to offer zen for astral diamonds
date: so you can grind astral diamonds and buy zen without spending any money...but since the people who buy zen are the ones who put a price
recommended: the amount of diamonds needed for a decent amount of zen is astronomical.\n\nNow you may think thats not a big deal since that doesnt necessary means the game is pay to win....well think again
hoursPlayed: you can actually see videos online of people soloing dungeons in the game because they bought high-level gear or special items like scrolls that allow you to resurrect the moment you are killed so the bosses health wont reset.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vU5ZpAs8aWE  <---- a perfect example of what i´m talking about"

reviewText: After having tried desperately to get into this game, I've given up hope. It took over a week to get an account registered. And now trying to log in through the launcher all I get is 'Could not validate conflict ticket. Please restart your launcher.'\nTried starting up as Admin, looked for a way to change the display name (some people reported having success that way) but in the end, all to no avail.\nI know it's free to play, I also know there's some pay-walls in the game. But if it's this much of an effort just to get it to run, why would I trust them with my money? Shame really, I love D&D games, really wanted to see this work :(

reviewText: For Neverwinter fans, it's not really the greatest game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: When you first start playing Neverwinter you're kind of taken aback at the vast world and deep storyline in front of you. You roll a few different character classes like you would in any MMO just to play around. It is at this point that you finally see Neverwinter's greatest flaw. Redundency. Every class feels like it plays exactly the same. Every dungeon run, even with different people plays exactly the same. In order to get any of the currency you need for trading on the auction house, or if you want to trade for paid currency, you have to play the same redundent dailys over and over again. Most MMOs don't really start to feel redundent until late game but Neverwinter seems to accomplish that after level ten.\n\nI really really wanted to like it, as I said before the story was quite good, and the character created quests seemed interesting but Neverwinter just gets bogged down by it's own redundency. If you want to play it with one charcter and stick to that one character all the way till max level just to experience the story that could be an okay experience. Venturing beyond that and trying to play the game as an MMO instead of a single player game and the magic" of game starts to truly fall apart."
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This would be a very nice game if it wasn't full of bugs, most of them very frustrating. Example: you finish a dungeon or skirmish and you can't get the reward chest because you are still in combat with some glitching add that you just can't see. I played a lot of MMORPGs and RPGs and had my share of bugs with each of them, but when it occurs as often as in Neverwinter, it makes you feel sorry about all the time wasted playing the game. I never met a game so bugged as this one and I understand this problem has been going on for years now. I never got an answer to the issues I made notices for from no GM, even after weeks after I posted them.\nConclusion? Although I understand it's a free-to-play game, the developer shows no respect to players however, therefore maybe they shouldn't be in the business after all.\nToo bad, this game could really have potential.

reviewText: I wish I could post a neutral review of this game.  It was very fun to start, all the way until level cap.  At which point, the pay to win started to show itself.  Unfortunately, it is impossible to have adequate gear to do ANYTHING but dailies (yawn) when you initially hit level cap.  I spent $100 on zen, converted it to ED, bought all the best gear I could on the AH at level cap.  And I still had a GS of only 12K.  That is completely unacceptable.  Not to mention how long it would have taken had I simply played enough to get that gear.\n\nFun until level cap, then worst game ever.  Then prepare to cry when every group you join for dungeons falls apart by the first group of mobs.  Every group of pvp has some twinked out rogues who have perma invisibilty and attack and then run off like pansies.  Only to do this repeatedly until you are murdered, without even touching them.

reviewText:
Neverwinter might have been a interesting light MMO but greed has destroyed the game.

The current policy in the game is to maximize profits at the exclusion of everything else. To that end nearly all development time is devoted to make more sellable items. The many bugs in the game, even the game breaking ones like dungeon chests always giving the same loot, go unaddressed for a long time. Exploits have destroyed the economy and using them has gone unpunished meaning that especially as new player you will be faced with prices you won't be able to pay even for simple items.
But as that means that some people might buy Zen for real money this was not addressed by Cryptic at all.

The prices of all items you can buy with real money are just laughable. $70 for a badly made race (they do not even have helmet textures) or $50 for skipping content (which is mind numbingly boring like all campaigns cryptic does but give permanent bonuses). To hide the true cost items can only rarely be bought separatly and are instead bundled together with lots of useless stuff. Cryptic is also not above using fake sales like selling the Dragonborn pack for $75 for a limited time instead of $100, but after the sale" ends they change the normal price to $75.

To keep players in line the official forums are patrolled heavily by mods and any mentioning of problems in the game will get the post deleted and you might also get banned. This includes warnings others about mislabeled "Bind on Equip" items which are instead "Bind on Pickup" (the current bug that shall not be named).

And finally Steam users are constantly harrased in the game as Cryptic wants to push their ARC launcher instead of steam. That means when you buy something through steam you are on probation for several weeks and face severe restrictions until Cryptic verifies that your money is good. And redeeming keys is only possible with the ARC launcher and not through a website.

Stay away from the game
date: the greedy practices of Cryptic and the neglect of actual issues is sucking all potential fun out of it."

reviewText: Pay to win.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros: The combat in the game is really fun, its not your tipical click and wait MMO. It feels more like an action adventure game, where position and dodging is key to survive.

Cons: A) BUUUUUUGSSSSSSS: The game was launched as a full game on june 2013, so you´ll think the game is in a playable state, yet the VERY FIRST DUNGEON in the game was bugged and to my knowledge to this day its still bugged and it cant be completed and the fourt dungeon you can access was also bugged and couldnt be completed. I understand that MMO may have bugs and glitches after release, but after a year, having your VERY FIRST DUNGEON IN THE GAME BUGGED IS UNACCEPTABLE....also crashes, falling through the map, dungeon bosses who wont drop any loot, etc

B) The time you spend leveling from 1 to 60 is the most repetitive process i have ever seen in an mmo. You start in a city, you get a quest to teleport to a certain area, you go there, accept a bunch of quest that involve either killing X amount of enemies or gather X amount of materials, you complete them and then you get 1 more quest that asks you to go to a unique instance and fight a mini boss, you go back to the quest giver who tells you to go to a different quest giver in a different part of the area, once you get there is the same thing...5 to 7 quest and then a miniboss, you do this 3 times before you are sent back to the city to go to a different area....AND THIS HAPPENS IN EVERY AREA, 5-7 quest, mini boss, do this 3 times and you are done with that area

C) Even though you can be a f2p without a problem, from lvl 1 to 60, everything in the game is hiden behind a paywall. Like any other MMO by perfect world enterteinment, the game has 3 different kinds of currency

1)Bronze, silver and gold coins: Classic mmo currency, that is basically useless, since the things you can buy with it are limited to potions, 1 single mount (a horse that comes in 6 differnet colors) and very low lvl gear.

2)Astral diamonds: Unique currency in the game that can be obtained by doing daily quest or by doing certain profession tasks. This is the most usefull currency in the game and so the hardest to get. You can use it to buy high lvl gear (you can pretty much avoid the dungeon grinding for gear at lvl 60 and buy a whole set of gear using diamonds) The auction house items can ONLY be bought with astral diamonds, unique mounts, cosmetics, basically everything that you cant buy with the previous currency must be bought with astral diamonds, especially the most important item in the game...the scroll of identification, that are used to idenfity gear so you can see the stats and wear it and since enemies have a higher chance of dropping gear than scrolls you are going to end up with a bag full of green or blue items that you cant wear because you dont have scrolls.

3) Zen: The universal currency of everysingle perfect world entertainment game, can only be bought with real-life money and you can use it to buy more astral daimonds or other items like keys used to open lockboxes or the most basic feature of every mmo out there...resseting your character stats in case you made a mistake, yep, you can only respec" your character if you pay real money...thankfully there is an in-game feature that allows real players to offer zen for astral diamonds
date: so you can grind astral diamonds and buy zen without spending any money...but since the people who buy zen are the ones who put a price
recommended: the amount of diamonds needed for a decent amount of zen is astronomical.\n\nNow you may think thats not a big deal since that doesnt necessary means the game is pay to win....well think again
hoursPlayed: you can actually see videos online of people soloing dungeons in the game because they bought high-level gear or special items like scrolls that allow you to resurrect the moment you are killed so the bosses health wont reset.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vU5ZpAs8aWE  <---- a perfect example of what i´m talking about"

reviewText:
Exceptionally Pay2Win game, which is a shame, because the game is actually well made. Even at the lowest levels the game lets you literally purchase so much power that you can be 3-4x as powerful as a free players on your level. This is especially noticable in pvp, where someone the same level as you can 3 shot you in less than 4 seconds, regardless of your gear or skill level.

This is also ade worse due to the class balance, letting some classes be 1.5-2x as powerful as others. Add Pay2win on top of a OP class, and you have a nearly-literal walking godmode, that can solo party dungeons with ease.

Avoid this wallet-warrioring game, unless your a whale.
