reviewText: When you first start playing Neverwinter you're kind of taken aback at the vast world and deep storyline in front of you. You roll a few different character classes like you would in any MMO just to play around. It is at this point that you finally see Neverwinter's greatest flaw. Redundency. Every class feels like it plays exactly the same. Every dungeon run, even with different people plays exactly the same. In order to get any of the currency you need for trading on the auction house, or if you want to trade for paid currency, you have to play the same redundent dailys over and over again. Most MMOs don't really start to feel redundent until late game but Neverwinter seems to accomplish that after level ten.\n\nI really really wanted to like it, as I said before the story was quite good, and the character created quests seemed interesting but Neverwinter just gets bogged down by it's own redundency. If you want to play it with one charcter and stick to that one character all the way till max level just to experience the story that could be an okay experience. Venturing beyond that and trying to play the game as an MMO instead of a single player game and the magic" of game starts to truly fall apart."

reviewText: This would be a very nice game if it wasn't full of bugs, most of them very frustrating. Example: you finish a dungeon or skirmish and you can't get the reward chest because you are still in combat with some glitching add that you just can't see. I played a lot of MMORPGs and RPGs and had my share of bugs with each of them, but when it occurs as often as in Neverwinter, it makes you feel sorry about all the time wasted playing the game. I never met a game so bugged as this one and I understand this problem has been going on for years now. I never got an answer to the issues I made notices for from no GM, even after weeks after I posted them.\nConclusion? Although I understand it's a free-to-play game, the developer shows no respect to players however, therefore maybe they shouldn't be in the business after all.\nToo bad, this game could really have potential.

reviewText:
This game is just a mess.

It's F2P, but it's impossible to play without constantly being reminded of the expensive in-game purchases. Early on I found myself getting some rare drops from the monsters, which all ended up being chests that I can open with a key I can buy for actual money to get a chance at getting rare gear.

The areas early on are bland. They are very, very generic fantasy castle zones colored in different shades of grey and brown. The game hasn't kept me entertained long enough to actually get further.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, there are things about this game which are really quite excellent.  I really like the crafting system, and the companions.  The best part by far is the Neverwinter Gateway - a website you can log into to run new crafting missions, and play a dice game which is actually kinda fun to level your companions, earn rewards, etc...

Aside from that though, the combat is a little boring, you have access to numerous skills, but can only ever have a few of them que'ed as active.  The zones are relatively small and linear, limiting your options and forcing you to play the way the devs want you to play.

And as you have read in numerous other reviews, this isn't really a free-to-play game, if you want to enjoy it (and have all the best toys) you have to spend money, lots of it.

It should be noted I didn't stick around for the end game, it just wasn't that interesting to make me think it was worth the time.

reviewText:
Game by Cryptic and Perfect World. It's an interesting game with a lot of intensive roleplay options, along with even more interesting monsters to kill and some interesting dialog to be read.

I got to level 60, but prior was already analyzing what the game really was about in terms of trade, chat, PvE/P content activity, etc.
What I was looking for exactly is:
Is there an LG? (Level Gap - Means there's an area where you will run into less then 5 players.)
Is it open world?
Do people take up on self made content? (Professions, LFW [Looking for Work], roleplay, guilds/clans, etc.)
PvP and it's aspects. (Is there a way to lone wolf and how can you conqueror at it.)
PvE and aspects. (Are quests dragging on, npc voice acting, npcs and pathing + activity)
How is the auction house? (Is it controlled by a select guild[s] or people, what is sold, LG?)
Can I avoid the Item Mall?

While Neverwinter is a pretty beautiful looking game there's no doubt, but it's locked a set FoV to make sure you think that. No, there is not a zoom in/out option so you have to type in a command to actually change your FoV. Worst of all is in the game you will see a lot of failed rendering and getting close to textures even on the maxed out settings...Shamefully blurry. Looks gorgeous at a distance, one they LOCKED down to make sure of that. If it's not failed rendering, it's bad glitches..From getting stuck in walls, not being able to use the /killme (/stuck) command to simply watching npcs run right through objects and hit you from triple the distance you can hit them at.

By no means am I a PvP all star, it's not my forte. Am I bad, not really, it's just something I see constantly being destroyed and generic. Neverwinter is no exception somberly. While the modes for PvP are extremely generic like Domination, the actual combat is much more interesting untill you realize the other team is in full PvP gear, and you're not. The difference amount in such is staggering. I have and never will believe in PvP power and resilience gear, it's stupid, unfair and incredibly hindering for new PvPers. Pathetically to say, this game can claim skill as much as it wants you will not be able to kill a person in full PvP gear even if it was 1 vs 10. That's how different PvP gear is to PvE.

As for PvE, it's just unfulfilling in my eyes. There was this level 18 - 22 zone I was in, and it gave me an option like Diablo and FPS Bots; Easy, Medium, Hard, Elite. I picked Elite because it sounded like fun, and for me to be fighting Battle-tested Orcs, Fire Wizard Orcs both elites, and giant Ogres plus the 10-15 normal archers and melee mobs...Happy is an understatement. I had to use skill to kill off the multiple Ogres and Elites and it was just too much entertainment. Pathetically, this isn't an option for every zone you enter. Frankly if there's no challenge, why play? I've played MMOs for over a decade, it's a reality for me, maybe not others.

Now let's go back to my list, and don't worry this is much shorter and sweet.
Questions & Answers:
Is there an LG? (Level Gap - Means there's an area where you will run into less then 5 players.)
>There's not much a level gap, 60s seem to be more then willing to help you out if they're not busy and you'll notice the dungeons really aren't hard at all. In fact they're very easy so long as you kill the major ones that can spawn mobs and heal.
Is it open world?
>It's not open world. It's battlezoned with one and only one major city. Which is f***ing pathetic in my eyes.
Do people take up on self made content? (Professions, LFW [Looking for Work], roleplay, guilds/clans, etc.)
>I can't be too sure yet if people really go into professions, I've yet to see weapons or armor for sale. No one is ever LFWing, as for roleplay, good luck. Doesn't exist at all from what I've seen. As for guilds, I'm not sure if anyone is even ever recruitting but that could just because the gold seller bots never stop. I mean never. You block one and two pop up within two minutes. This isn't a joke I've f***ing timed it. Two hours straight. They never missed a second. What worries me is I'd see a lot of legit names that players would have like GrimReaper" etc. and it makes me wonder if account hacking is a problem!
PvP and it's aspects. (Is there a way to lone wolf and how can you conqueror at it.)
>Yeah
date: you can lone wolf it pretty easily. "Skill" + PvP gear... = 1 v 5 me bro lol u nub ded..... /♥♥♥♥INGSIGH\nPvE and aspects. (Are quests dragging on

reviewText:
The game looks nice, the combat is very fun and engaging.  It's definitely a different take on MMO combat compared to other games I've played.  The character builds seem to have variety and depth, but I can't say for certain as I'm not max level.

Unfortunately, that's where the good stops.

The game is garbage.  You get nickel and dimed every two minutes.  If you want to succeed in the game you have to participate in the worst MMO activity ever invented - dailies.  Alternatively, cash shop.

Beyond that, the rest of the game sucks as well.  It's extremely linear.  It is not open world.  There are ? and !'s above people's heads.  The group combat is faceroll.  Literally.  Play a healer, go to dungeon, roll face on keyboard.  Bet no one dies and nobody even notices that you didn't do anything.  The quests are boring and your actions do not affect the world in anyway.

There is no PvP outside of instances as far as I can tell.  The game is literally 95% PvE, even moreso than WoW.

The game would be far better if it was subscription base not f2p.  Unfortunately, beyond the combat mechanics, the rest of the game sucks so I wouldn't subscribe anyways.

reviewText:
Exceptionally Pay2Win game, which is a shame, because the game is actually well made. Even at the lowest levels the game lets you literally purchase so much power that you can be 3-4x as powerful as a free players on your level. This is especially noticable in pvp, where someone the same level as you can 3 shot you in less than 4 seconds, regardless of your gear or skill level.

This is also ade worse due to the class balance, letting some classes be 1.5-2x as powerful as others. Add Pay2win on top of a OP class, and you have a nearly-literal walking godmode, that can solo party dungeons with ease.

Avoid this wallet-warrioring game, unless your a whale.

reviewText:
I haven't played this game for too long, but what i saw did not impress me. Let me point out why it didn't.

1. Graphics: I don't have that good of a computer, which sucks. With newer mmorpgs, i have to turn it to low to avoid lag. In this, not only was it horrible looking on low, it lagged quite a bit. AA looked and ran better. So in short, the graphics are dependent on your pc. For me, they were horrible, with heavily pixilated details when they appeared.

2. Gameplay: Now, this is the main reason I played the game for more than an hour. You have a smaller hotbar of skills, making you think about what skills you will pick. I played the Guardian guy, and the combat was solid. It was similar to Tera in you don't just click and target, you do each slash individually. And if you play the class I did, you can actually block with your shield, which is small byt refreshing. You also have this ultimate skill which is pretty cool. Overall, ifound the combat fun. A little easy, and it can become repetitive, but fun.

reviewText:
I purchased this thinking that Dragon Born would have the option to select Bahamut as a diety and that there would be some unique dialogue and/or content associated with the various Dragon Born NPCs around the Faerun world.  I was, sorely, disappointed.  All of the Dragon Born NPCs treat you as if you are just another adventurer instead of one of their own.  Cryptic was lazy and did not create any helmet art other than the 2 pieces that come in the pack.  One is for a ceremonial fashion set and the other simple overlapping plates on the head.  The 'toon' looks ridiculous on a horse, so if you are one those who wants your character to look cool, you will have to buy (with real money) a larger mount.  To get the Metalic Dragon skins, you will have to gamble your way thru lockboxes, that are only available for Astral Diamonds, and buy however many keys (about $1.25 each) it takes to get it.

The other content is okay.  The bag helps to keep from having to find a vendor all the time, The Heart of the Red dragon artifact helps at low levels and the ring is okay.  The rest of it is just fluff.  You can't even use the overloads until you reach 60th level and then only in special sets of armor you have to grind your way to get.

Not worth $75.  Not even worth the $60 I paid for it while it was on sale.  If you just have to have the dragon born race, spend the $25 to get a race reroll token (less if you get an in-game coupon for 15% off any zen market item).  The race reroll token can be use, after creating a regular character, to reroll it as a dragon born.

reviewText:
I found this game through Steam but played mostly without Steam.

I have two lvl70 chars, a Scourge Warlock, the first one, and the Oathbound Paladin, my main char now.

At first this game felt amazing. Beautiful graphics (I turn off Post Processing and Bloom because I don't like the result, performance is amazing here even at 2560x1440 with everything maxed out), lots of customizations and classes, races, quests, refinements, wow. A lot to discover and try, so a lot of fun.

After a while I found I was stuck, or the progress was slowing down a lot, and the main cause was clear: unless spending real money I could never have enough to keep progressing.

And when I could try the content to better geared chars, the game turned into a complete mess. We have, for example, Valindra's Tower, Malabog's Castle and Epic Lair of Lostmauth. You need to wait in a virtual line to get in any of those. Sometimes you wait for 30 minutes, 40 minutes, or even more. And when you can go in, lag lag lag. And by lag, I really really mean it. You start to rubberband a lot, timewarp a lot, commands take 1 to 2 seconds to work. I listed Valindra's Tower, Malabog's Castle and Epic Lair of Lostmauth. After maybe two months doing quests while waiting to enter these, the first two were absolutely unplayable with most people simply leaving due to the lag. I coundn't finish the first two due to that. The Epic Lair of Lostmauth I finished only once, and when I did, the price, a chest for you to open and pick your rewards bugged and I couldn't pick anything. So I tried again and again over and over (I needed the armor and due to the lag I could't foresee any other chance to get it), maybe 20 tries or more, and it worked. I recorded a video showing this.

Well, after playing for a while and playing A LOT everyday, I ended only logging to do some daily quests to advance in the campaigns.

And my chars are stuck because I'm not putting any money on this game because it feels like they may change important things anytime; because I can't play very important parts of the game, the most difficult and rewarding ones, due to lag and bugs; because paying is the only way to succed here. And you need to pay a lot.

Note that I don't even mention PVP. PVP in this game is the most stupid thing I ever seen.

EDIT: I forgot to say that my forst char was abandoned because it was a god until lvl60 but after that turned into suffering and frustration, dying all the time to anything. I kept playing with it until after the lvl70 (and two or three excess lvls so I have many things maxed out to IV) but the char kept dying over and over again, too weak for anything. I tried different gear, different combination of stats, maxing defense, maxing deflection, maxing power, arpen, crit, making it balanced, nothing worked.

Then I created the OP and even before the lvl70, when I was like lvl67, I was destroying everything the first char couldn't even face. The difference is HUGE. I can leave this char afk in the same places where the first char can't even walk in alone.

This game is unbalanced like hell.

reviewText: It's free-to-play, very full-featured, and a ton of fun if you like fantasy MMOs. Uses the Dungeons & Dragons 4th Edition rules, which actually work a lot better as a computer game than they do in the pen & paper game. The combat is surprsingly robust, much more interactive than in a typical MMO - it uses reticule targeting rather than Tab targeting, and that's a LOT more interesting. The big bonus is the built-in Foundry editor which allows any user to create their own quests, so there's a huge amount of user generated content, some of it very good indeed.\n\nOverall, it's currently my go-to MMO, and I recommend it highly.

reviewText:
Played a Control Wizard, some things I thought so far.
- It's fun, most quests have dialogue, loots
- The game uses autotarget with a centered cursor, no tabbing through enemies
- Enemies are pulled in groups, so combat is similar to Old Republic, light, medium, boss enemies
- Feels much more like an ARPG than an mmo, dodge, stuns, positional attacks
- Some quests lead to instanced areas, they feel like mini dungeons

Solid fun so far ... and it's free

reviewText:
It's difficult for me to classify Neverwinter as an MMO. I feel a much better description would be a dungeon hack-and-slash with some MMO trappings. Character customization is bare bones, even leaving out the fact that certain iconic races are locked away behind the pay wall. You're able to choose your character's sex, race, and class along with his/her origin and patron deity. The latter two are surprisingly limited, given the setting; even in 4th Edition's greatly reduced pantheon, there are a number of gods and goddesses worshipped by the people of Faerun, yet the game only gives you a fraction. Likewise, the origins only cover a handful of locales in the Realms. It quickly becomes apparent that this game was not made for diehard fans of Forgotten Realms.

If you're looking for a worthy successor to Neverwinter Nights, you will not find it in this game. The Foundry is a poor substitute for that legendary series' robust world-building and DM tools, with even the most highly regarded player-created dungeons essentially boiling down to the same formulaic hack-and-slash gameplay of the main game. I cannot recommend this game to anyone looking for a meaningful MMO experience. With a friend or two, some fun can be had in  fighting your way through waves of kobolds and orcs so long as you keep your expectations in check.

Overall: Pass

reviewText:
It's fun if you like endless pve questing, with tons and tons of gear, crafting stuff, etc. (and of course a cash shop).
The pvp is totally unbalanced. The problem seems that there is no real efficient tiering to pvp against other players with similiar gear, and the crowd control means perm-stun.
Great for pve, fail for pvp.

Edit:
The pvp is compete nonsense, worst i have ever seen: a breakdown of gaming balance fundamentals. It's about meta game with rediculous chain disables and phase teleportations. There is no cooldown for crowd control and you get perma stun, repeated again and again. You can't let pve ez mode overkill abilities and gear get into pvp, it's unbalanced.
Also, to be able to use p2w gear in pvp is the worst fail of all.

The pve side of the game is very enjoyable, and i liked the queue'd public dungeons. I wouldn't ever take a game with this cash model seriously, because it has no real goal, except to hustle you to spend more than you should just to get the content (gear). I do believe in spending some money to support f2p games, and even support a subcription fee for a great game, in which case i would expect ALL content, gear and items , which this game and many others wont do.

reviewText: I am actually not certain whether to recommend this game or not.  It is entertaining in many ways.  However, I played Neverwinter since the beta and many bugs still exist after approximately one year of release (and several patches--which focused on the zen market most of the time).  The inadequate class balancing makes it frustrating for those who love PVP (only specific classes are worth taking into PVP).  If you have played Dungeons & Dragons PnP style, you will find that this game is not entirely D&D (I believe it is stated in the game description that they used modified 4e rules).  If you are looking for something closer to real D&D, Dungeons & Dragons Online is the way to go.  Unfortunately, something about DDO that seems to fail to grasp my interest for a longer duration.  On the other hand, I found myself playing Neverwinter only to collect diamonds during my daily invocation and whenever there is an event.  I think the Foundry is its main asset for now.  As a former Dungeon Master, I wish I have the time to invest in creating quests in the Foundry.\n\nI would like to recommend this game because it is somewhat enjoyable to play.  However, I just find it hard to recommend at this point because of issues that the developers should have fixed a long time ago (graphics bugs, game launcher crashing every so often, game patching can be buggy to some people, some dungeons are frustrating to run because of bugs, some quests/areas/dungeons become buggy right after patching--sometimes to the point of getting stuck and not be able to proceed or appropriate loot not dropping, highly expensive items in the market, and more).  If Steam had the option to take the middle ground, I would have picked it because the game is not a horrible game.

reviewText: Graphics look like they're from the late '90s, even on the max settings, and the combat feels antiquated. Why play this when you could shell out a small amount and play a more modern MMO like Black Desert Online, etc, or one with a stronger developer like WoW? The only thing going for this game is that it's F2P to start, but you'll quickly realize you'll have to spend a bit for a reasonable experience. This is basically WoW-lite.

reviewText:
Incredibly fun MMO with heavy D&D feel (but just the fun parts!). Make your own quests! Auto-grouping while killing huge dargons/L337 baddies! Fun combat and pvp, though they could use a few more pvp maps.

Crafting system is pretty fun, time-based and anyone can do anything, you can even craft on your phone while away from PC, but I was very sad when they nerfed the ♥♥♥♥ out of leadership, and removed it from mobile.


Plus I enjoyed sliding around on my cleric like the dude from Risky Business.

9/10 will slide around some more.

*Edit* This review was based on the last time I played, maybe 6mos ago. Now, sadly I must agree with many of the other reviewers that this game is no longer worth it.

Once upon a time it was fun on a bun, but now its a looooong boring grind unless you're into that pay-to-win thing. Which I am not. So my 9/10 is demoted to 4/10, because its still pretty and the combat is still fun, but the endgame is crap and the grind is too much. RIP Neverwinter, once loved, now shunned.

reviewText:
*Warning, this could happen to you at anytime, better to invest your money in games handled by a competent company*

I will have nothing to do with any thing attached to perfectworld from here and in the future. I've played this as well as other games from this company, I have money invested that I will never get back. Something has gone wrong with their code authentication service. I've checked forums and it seems I'm not the only one to have this problem so FYI this is not an isolated issue and it could happen to you as well at anytime.
After any fresh install when you try to login to any of their games it asks for a one time code that is supposed to be sent to your registered e-mail. I do not receive any codes ever. Spent way too much time with support getting me to do all kinds of runaround ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, changing e-mails, reset password etc. etc...
There is no problem on my end, I have even done a full HD reformat and reinstall of windows and the problem remains. They simply won't bother to fix their broken code system and you are completely unable to access any of their games without it.
Enjoy what money I have spent in the past on your games PW, I will avoid anything you handle in the future like the plague!

reviewText:
If you liked D & D this is not for you. 60 levels of fetch later - I now feel like the exciting genre I used to cherish has become a tired room full of stinky old man farts.

Worse it's pretty. The gameworld is like a beautiful girl you're getting to know and then at the magic moment she tells you you have to pay and that all of your frenemies already did, and did it on your gaming-chair. The constant reminder to buy in game purchases utterly destroyed any fun you were about to have with your friends too. The pretty game just told you that you probably weren't good enough to have fun without getting another job for more bling, and they should start paying too if they're gonna come over to HER place. Fun-less.

So all in all I'd say this was about as disappointing as finding out that Santa wasn't real and that the dude mommy's been kissing all these years was just Jerry Seinfeld's pudgy, unemployed buddy Geoge.

reviewText:
Good Game
Good Graphics
Poor Managment/Developers

The game graphics are good, the play style can be very fun, but the developers are so far behind the curve for MMO's its sad, they're barely implementing concepts common to MMO's now in their 8th Mod/expansion in 2 years.  I've been playing since July 2015, and it's extremely easy to level characters to play End-Game content, but so repetitive when you finally get to the end-game content that you want to start another character just to enjoy something different to break the monotony.
And they've finally figured out that the best way to make money is to essentially force players to buy most everything via ZEN  which is predominantly purchased with Real World Money.. because they've created numerous mechanisms e.g. Bound to Account BoA and Bound to Character BoC items that you are guarenteed to have inventory issues requiring buying Bank Slots(ZEN)  buying Bags (ZEN).  Other mechanisms that require ZEN are the Astral Diamond Exchange (Astral Diamond - AD) an in-game currency; which like most every MMO, they've made so many mistakes creating an economy for, that people exploited the hell out of it.. and made massive piles of AD  making the exchange market a joke for any peron who wasn't either exploiting it or buying it with Real World Money.
The next way to soak up your time and money is in the form of Artifacts; Artifacts are weapons and equipment that are mostly End-game items, there are numerous artifacts you can have from around level 20, but the weapons and equipment will not be avaialbale till a player reaches level 70(Max level)  and can only be upgraded with Refining Stones and a few other very Minor things like lvl 60+ weapons, and considering it will take so many of these items that the people making money on refining stones and refinment items is split about 70/30  Exploiters-Botters/Cryptic  the exploiters run mass amounts of bots farming anything they can sell on the Astral Diamond exchange and Cryptic expects you to buy most everything else from them to actualy complete and finish refining an item to make it more powerful.
Other than Cryptic's lame claim that they are trying to make the game playable for people with time to play" and people "with money to play" they are very definitely focused on soaking money from people in the latter category.
The most annoying thing beyond the money grab is that the game has so many glitches and development screw-ups that if you enjoy playing all of the content and reading all of the stories and background.. you may miss a whole lot
date: because they've broken nearly every Dungeon that isn't part of End-Game content and if you level too fast or power level you will not be able to go back and finish any of it
recommended: because they're too focused on keeping up the End-game content and keeping people paying that they're avoiding fixing the lower level dungeons.  The easy fix has been in most every other MMO i've played
hoursPlayed: You power leveled past some stuff
voteText: so you join with a group of people to play that older content and your overall level etc is reduced back to the level of the content.  But 5+ mods/expansion later and they're still ignoring that massive gaping hole --that DnD fans like the content and the story--

reviewText:
This surprised me, for a f2p its not bad.

Pros: PvE this is where the game shines.  There's different  queues for dungeons and skirmishes (team up with people to defeat an outdoor mini dungeon) for your level range.  There's also the foundry which has thousands of player made content which is always being updated and keeps things fresh.  You can of course create a foundry mission which the community can play and applies to the previous statement.

Cons: The classes have balancing issues in pvp and if people have better gear than  you then you'll get rolled but if you farm enough you can get the same gear but its mildly pay to win.  There's class issues in PvE as well for instance I played a tank (so  called) which would lead you to believe you would tank, hold aggro, and be a damage sponge.  This is not the case.

You spend most of your time  running out of the red spots as a tank, which means you aren't dps'ing, which means you're not generating enough threat to hold aggro.  If you stand  in the red and don't block you take huge damage...as a fully geared tank, and spec'ed full tank (I tried both the tank trees in full defensive gear 51% dmg reduction, 32% parry which is very high, and 15% aoe reduction, a large hp pool, among other things) you take massive damage.

Your only hope is to use your aoe taunt which has a long cooldown, and spam your fighters recovery daily which unless you're tactician you wont have up when you  need it so thats the  only viable spec I've found.  The so called cookie cutter spec is to stack attack power and go down the tree  that gives you double attack power if you have full block (which means if you block your dps is lowered based on how much shield you have remaining).  This is great for threat, but you can't take much damage and the healing in  this game is pretty bad imo.  This saddens me as I only had an interest in tanking in NW and they've failed the class.  Tanks aren't taken most of the time end game, people would rather have ranged and cc ( ranger and control wizard) control means no healing and more aoe damage potential.

Until they fix the tank class to be able to actually tank I wont be playing the game.

============================================================

I did create a foundry mission which was very time consuming (you can spend as much or as little time as you wish on a foundry mission) as I chose to build my own multi-story building (very limited tools made this a lot harder than  it needed to be, for example, if you could select more than one object to copy / paste, it  would have saved me days of work if not more).

The community can rate your foundry mission in a 5 star system if they play it and for the most part the community in the foundry is good.  But since most people don't create foundry missions, they don't appreciate how long it takes to make them.  If you want an example do a search for my foundry mission Ghost - behind enemy lines" and play it.  That foundry took me over 3 weeks to make and I'm out of work so that means every day I was working on it (most of the time was building the last building).

Its not all bad though
date: I went into the foundry  sort of knowing it would take a while and some people would be unappreciative but for the most  part the reviews were friendly and the comments some people had were very  satisfying and thoughtful.  People can donate astral diamonds to you if they wish and a lot of people do so that's nice.  If the community rates it high enough it can be hosted by the devs.   People play your content and enjoy it
recommended: that makes you feel like you wrote a novel (which you actually are an author in this case) and people like it
hoursPlayed: this makes it worth it."

reviewText:
Curiously, I actually enjoy this game. The game itself is a strong MMO, if a bit outdated on the graphics end.

My reasons for giving a bad review is the 'free to play' claim. While I have no real issue with a game that allows players to purchase the best gear, this should be a shortcut - nothing more. It is technically true that players CAN access the paid content by trading in-game currency for ZEN (the real money currency), the amount of time to get even a small quantity is highly limiting. But this isn't the major problem. The major problem I have is that it seems like everything in the game is locked behind that pay-wall; need more bags? Zen. A mount upgrade? Zen. Bank slots? Zen. Character slots? Zen. Re-spec? Zen. Access to the [current] best-in-slot gear? Zen. Better companions? Zen. Upgrade companions? Zen (or an astronomical anount of ingame currency). And the prices are, quite frankly, offensive: 16 bank slots on a single character? That'll run you about $6. That's more than a character slot. Some mounts are $40. The lowest rank bag? $6. Whoever priced this stuff needs to lose his job - and everyone who actually paid these prices is only enabling this mess. I want to see the game succeed, because I enjoy playing it. But that isn't going to happen if everyone actually pays their exorbant prices.

Finally, I was forced to post this here because the developers refuse to allow posts about thier 'pay to win' pricing at all in their forums. They know it's an issue, and their response is to be adversarial - they clearly don't treat their customers with respect and think of them as little more than piggy banks.

reviewText:
Neverwinter for PC is an outstanding MMORPG from what I have experienced. I have not gotten to a maximum level yet, and I'm not a Neverwinter expert, but based off of my 22.9-hour-impression,  I highly reccomend this game for anybody looking for an MMORPG.

Pros:
-free to play (all levels for everyone, features like being in a party open to everyone, etc)
-good graphics
-lots of useful video settings
-proper third person view (moving the mouse to turn character)
-default controls are simple and open to edit
-useful guidance to locations for quests (sparkling line, not pointing arrow)
-most things in the game do not require real money
-slightly automatic aiming, useful if you're a bad aimer or using a gamepad

Cons:
-not compatible with gamepads / console controllers (although it will work if you use your own installed key binding program)
-mounts (creatures that you may ride on) must be purchased with the zen currency which is difficult to get unless you buy it with real money
-a couple of races require an expansion pack that you must pay real money for

IMO (In My Opinion):
-better than any MMORPG I've played
-very fun

reviewText:
I'd say it's one of the better free to play games out there, but with that being said, there are some faults with it. Since it is a F2P MMO, there is obviosly going to be a microtransactions store. However, I wouldn't exactly say that it is pay to win.

With the aiming and casting mechanics, early game is fast paced and fun. The only problem I have with this game is the end-game. After reaching the max level, everything becomes a daily quest. You log in, do the quests, claim your reward, maybe replay your favorite dungeons, and then get off. It becomes tedious and boring after a while.

If you're looking for a casual MMO to get into where you don't have to farm for hours on end, give this game a try.

reviewText: As a long-time player of the Neverwinter Nights series, this game practically screamed my name to play. I was reluctant at first, however, because a FTP MMORPG that my friends said sucked was not very enticing...\n\nHOWEVER this game is THE ABSOLUTE BEST MMO out there. No joke. And it's FTP!!! It runs on crappy machines even, so you have no excuse not to try it. It is kind of a combination of WOW and TESO, providing all the things those games lack. It is a hack and slash with abilities that tops all other point and click MMOs (or any MMO for that matter). One thing to point out is it is much more fun with a friend, so bring a buddy (or four!). I would pay big bucks to play an amazing game like this, and it is even more so amazing that it is free. 10/10 already one of my favorite games of all time!

reviewText:
Hands down one of the best free MMOs I have ever played.

The game is not the most gorgeous, but it looks good.  The game is not incredibly complex, but it has an intricate balance.  I really enjoyed my time in the game... and even outside of it.

The dynamic of playing the game from a browser with my companions is brilliant.  The fact that I can craft from the same browser is amazing!  If they had an app that did something similar, I'd almost pay a small monthly fee for it.

The companion system by itself is actually pretty awesome.  Someone to hang out with you and support or tank or fill whatever gap you have is pretty awesome.  While some of them could stand to be a little better, they are pretty good overall and the ones at the beginning of the game are very helpful.

My favorite part, however, is the user created content.  The ability to run a dungeon" created by another player is amazing.  I've run some good ones and bad ones
date: but that feature is awesome!  When I say dungeon
recommended: it does it a bit of dis-service.  It is more like an entire zone built with encounters
hoursPlayed: buildings
voteText: bosses and loot tables that plays out as a full quest or mission.  Some of them can be done in 10 or 20 minutes
helpfulPercent: while others may take more than hour.  The difficulty is also variable.\n\nThe micro-transactions for this game can get pricey
votesHelpful: but I didn't worry too much about them.  They have some interesting packs and people who plan to invest a lot of time can easily wait until a sale and get a great deal.  IMO
votesTotal: the game is good enough to at least invest a little bit."

reviewText: I have been seeing a lot of negative reviews saying the game is pay to win. If you are going to try out the game, know one thing: you will not start to make a good amount of AD, the main currency, until you hit the max level (60). The game's economy is mostly based around the player base and player market. Items that you get from endgame dungeons will either be worth 500 AD or 500,000 AD depending on how badly the buyer wants said item. For instance, I earned a piece of armor a few days ago that sold for 600,000, but today it is worth around 150,000. You may also exchange AD for the premium currency, Zen, which you have the option to pay actually money for. The only thing you can not get in game without paying actually money are the packs which are really not a big deal.\n\nThis is my most played game on steam and I personally think it is very underrated. The questing can feel a bit grindy but it is almost fully voice acted. There is also great deal of lore is case you want to get into it. Otherwise the combat is very quick and responsive, the loot and customization is executed very well, and I feel the game should have a much bigger playerbase.

reviewText:
Did you like the old Neverwinter Night games? Then skip Neverwinter!
Did you play Dungeons & Dragons pen-n-paper? Then skip Neverwinter!

Neverwinter is a very shallow action MMORPG with avarage graphics and a badly optimized game engine. Having a mid-high end PC myself, both my GPUs will run at 80%-99% most of the time because of the bad engine, and it already has fried an old GPU of mine >:( When settling for less active GPU usage, the graphics just become plain ugly.

Neverwinter has a D&D tag on it, but it's extremely loosely based on the D&D4 rules (which I think are the worse around). And Forgotten Realms and Neverwinter? The devs obviously glanced into the lore and thought they'd got it all. Well, you never can grasp the whole Realms in just a couple of months - it takes years of ACTIVE roleplaying there to know what's going on and Neverwinter shows it just fine. NPC factions in places where they should not be, NPC characters that have been dead for ages that are alive again, even while there was totally no chance on ressurection whatsoever.

reviewText:
This game is SOOOOOOOO ADDICTING... Ive played so many mmorpgs but i usually end up quiting cuz of the long, boring and endless hours of grinding. However this game is always action packed with the large amount of bosses/dungeons. You level up quickly from following the main quests so it keeps gamers from getting bored of doing the same thing. Dungeons also get SUPER epic when you have a full party of 5 especially when you get later into the game. (level 45+)

Graphics are amazing at full HD quality, character customization is awesome (get to choose races, jobs etc), combat system is great (similar to Tera Rising)-- dodge/block system, PVP is fun (kinda like capture the flag or Dominion in League of Legends), overall game can be competitive (mechanically skilled players can outplay other players with op stuff), and much more.

I reached the max level 60, and during that experience it was HELLA FUN! And it gets way better cuz once you hit 60, you get bombarded with more crazy quests and you can customize your character even more with the access to boons (another skill tree). Overall I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME! It's just amazing bcuz you can have the same amount of fun by yourself or by grabbing some of your buddies to do the dungeons/quests with.

10/10

reviewText:
You definetly should not try this game if you hate pay to win games.I've played this game,before release,before it came to steam.It was the best game of my life,until I hit max level,thats where you are pressured to spend real money.PvP to the best of my knowledge,end game wise:HAS ALWAYS BEEN F***ING PAY TO WIN.

To the best of my knowledge the best way to get maximum satisfaction from this game is to DELAY YOUR LEVELING PROGRESS AS MUCH AS YOU CAN.Don't do the questing areas,focus on daily quests for PvP and Foundry.When I was playing this,the leveling areas where both a grind fest and a runing simulator,I dare compare it to ESO(from what I saw on twitch and youtube),but this did not have a way point sistem when I played it.

Story wise and time consuming wise,foundry quests are better,and can be replayed anytime(at least that was the case before I quit this pay to win bear trap),compared to the stuff done by PWE and Cryptic.The dungeon quees at low levels were decent in my day,I hope they did not tighten the pay wall since I left to make low level pve pay to win as well.

This is the kind of game that I recomend you should play when you're favorite mmo/moba is on maintenance for a whole day.The pay to win aspects were so strong that I had to quit the game,end game pvp is a farse desingend to eat up your whole wallet.

The combat of this game is absolutely the best I have exeprienced and it made me want to do pvp in mmo's,that's how good the combat is,it turned me away from being pve focused to a balanced mmo player(I now like both pvp and pve in mmo's,before this I hated pvp because all of the mmo's I played were tab based and seemed both dull and complicated,I was a proper scrub,until Neverwinter my first action combat based mmo),but they took it to far.

Everything other people say in their reviews about the economy sistem is true,it has been so since release.

To conclude this review,I recomend it for players who have friends to play with in pvp and foundries.I also recomend this for people who are new to mmo's because this game offers you the best and worst of the mmo genre,giving players awareness on what to look out for in their next mmo,market wise.Avoid this if you are a SOLO,EXPERIENCED MMO PLAYER,you might quit this game before you get your first purple item,I sure as hell did.

reviewText:
As someone who has played other D&D games before, but has not played the pen & paper game, Neverwinter felt very accessible. It has the most enjoyable combat out of any MMOs that I have played to date.

As a free-to-play game, it has a real money (referred to as Zen) cash shop. While all of the items in the cash shop seem expensive, I never felt like I was required to purchase any of them to enjoy the content that everyone else was playing. As you play, you can earn the in-game currency, Astral Diamonds, and exchange it with other players for the Zen that they have purchased. Depending on what you are looking to purchase, the length of the grind required varies dramatically.

As for content, the Foundry and its infinite content" is a nice distraction from the developer made quest line. Some of the quests that players have created are absolutely ridiculous
date: both in personality and in quality.\n\nI highly recommend giving Neverwinter a shot and forming your own decision. It doesn't take that long to reach the level cap
recommended: and it's free - what do you have to lose?"

reviewText:
Is it the best F2P mmorpg out there? The short answer is no. There are a lot of things that are a problem, and most of these centre around the business model of the devs. That being said it is still entirely possible to enjoy yourself if you are looking for a drop in/drop out online exp. The vast majority of the negative reviews are born out of the gaming communities disgust at having to spend actual money on a game they are playing for free. Let that sentence roll around for a moment.

Very simply it boils down to whether or not you are looking for a suitable end game experience. If you have a lot of money to burn then this is the game for you. If, however, you would like everything to be free in this world (I think someone once said some about the price of a lunch...) then this is not for you.

If you, like me, are just looking for a casual and beautiful online experience to jump into every now and again, then I would say go for it. After all, it is free.

reviewText:
Updated review ( Everything after 420 hours playtime  is lvl 70/mod8 content)

Neverwinter is an action  F2P MMORPG with faster lvling than wow , interesting combat and 8 modules (mini expansions all for free)

IS the game P2W? Not really you can pay and get things faster but it should be more than possible to get full epic lvl 70 gear and ViP rank12 plus mounts all for free once you get to lvl 70 and do some grinding.

PROS:

-The game + modules are 100% free you can even get VIP without paying!
-The combat is diffrent and interesting.
-Clean and easy to use UI, no more 50 hotkeys to clog your screen.
-You can earn a decent amount of ingame currency and buy the same stuff as wallet warriors.
-Lvling from lvl1-60 is very fast.
-Free Artefact weapon just by reaching lvl 70.
-Free stuff from ingame store during hollidays (mounts,bags, refining stuff )
-Ignore lists are account wide(take that gold spammers)
-Most lvl 70 equipment is accountbound.
-The mod 8 equipment is easy to get and very good.
-Minc the character you quest with at lvl 60-70 is hillarious.
-Do a  cool questline made by R.A Salvatore.
-Fight alongside Drizzt Do'Urden.


CONS:

-Game can be laggy even on high end computers.
-Disconnections happen at the most inconvenient times.
-PVP is a bit unbalanced and you will find yourself with a crappy team vs premade.
-If you have low itemlvl no good guild will take you in.
-Lvling from lvl 60-70 takes way too long, wanted to shoot myself in the foot.
-Some items on the AH is way overpriced.
-If you are not in a guild you will have no more quests at lvl 68 ish.
-The Devs removed ALOT of cool dungeons when lvl 70 came out, they might come back tho.
-Gold is useless
-Goldspammers are annoying and everywhere, just like wow.


So after all this, do I still reccomend the game? yes, because I am having alot of fun and my guild is doing lvl 70 stuff
My personal opinion is that the Pros outweight the cons even when you fight a wallet warrior in pvp haha.

My score 8/10 (could be worse , a few bugfixes and some old dungeons back from the devs and I will bump it up to 9)

reviewText:
Having logged a significant amount of time and after finally taking a serious interest in this game I think it is time for a review.

Why you should play NW: (i.e. Is it worth the time)
If you have enjoyed playing MMOS in the past (wow,Tera,vindictus, etc..) you should try NW and if your new to MMOS it's a great starting point.
For grizzled MMO vets it is a nice refresher with great combat, a wide array of skills and powers, and an economy that is pretty stable (for now). The PvE is interesting and a fun thing to run through, it's got great visuals and a large amount of characters. PvP is also present in a big way. The que system is well organized and there is even ranked play. There are also whole different play styles based on pvp (different armor to use, powers, feats, items, etc). The game itself has great visuals and any graphics hungry max setting fps PC behemoth computer builders have a chance to go nuts graphics wise. (Don't worry it also runs on toasters). End game content ramps up the PvE and PvP in a big way with campaigns and artifacts so tons of play value after basic lvling campaign is done. Also like all MMOS you got your guilds and they have events and it's all hunky dory (if you can't tell I tend to solo play).

If you are new to MMOS NW is great because it in a sense is simple. It guides you in the beginning better than any MMO I have seen. The combat is quick to grasp but still fun and interesting. Figuring out your play style/kit you use comes easily as you settle into your character.

Problems with Neverwinter.
Holy ♥♥♥♥ we got somethings to talk about: (keep in mind despite all this I still love/am addicted to NW)
First and foremost: this game in a significant manner is pay to win. Endgame PVP is ruined by people that can decimate you due to there incredibly overpowered kits. Seeing a guy that has almost 3x the gear score you have in the same pvp match as you leaves some very lasting effects on my opinion of pvp. Anyway back to the pay system. I recommend that you invest at least a little cash in this game as a jumping off point once you reach lvl 70 just because you won't last a second in pvp if you don't. I wish there was no pay system and we could just upfront pay for Neverwinter so the title Free To Play wasn't slapped on it. Just invest a little on enchantments. And a mount and refining and more refining and even more refining (you get the point)

The refining system: ok so in this game there are artifacts that you have to charge with refining points to make them better (also enchantments to charge but eh ♥♥♥♥ that). Currently the final ranks of artifacts vary (legendary/mythic) to get to legendary takes waaaayyyyyyyy to many refining points so don't even get me started on mythic. This system in principle is good in practice but holy ♥♥♥♥ it takes to long. Cryptic, listen, do everyone a solid and make refining less of a grind and give us some time left on our lives. Seeing people run around with all mythic gear makes me seriously question the state of their bank account or the state of their social life( no offense no lifers). I can't imagine the time it would take to do that.

Back to PVP: ok so pvp as a game type is great. Capture the points on a 5 on 5 match, fun, simple, organized BUT!!!! BUTT!!!!!!!!! It is so unbalanced. Once in a millennia do I find a game where it is a hard fought good game between two relatively even teams that comes down to a last push or last second play. Almost always there is a clear winner from the beginning. This is always attributed to mismatched gear scores. I should not be a guy with a gear score of 2,600 facing a guy with a GS of 4,500 (measured as of 2/16/16, measuring of gear scores has changed before). Fix this please. Organize it by rank or gear score or whatever, even if it takes longer to que it will be worth it.

Alone vs Party play: if I can recommend anything to newcomers is find a friend early on. I choose to play solo (my choice can't blame the game) but it is hard. Forget dungeon delving alone it can't be done (except you 4.5k GS guy) also things can get a little grindy sometimes and it is nice to have a friend during this time. Also 2 heads are better than 1, NW offers a lot especially lvl 60 and up. Having a friend to help figure things out with will benefit you in many ways. This is less a criticism and more a helpful recommendation. Find a friend or find a guild do it early or be prepared you brave soul.

FINAL NOTE:
Despite these minor problems ( the few lines of code Satan himself added) I still love NW. Why I don't entirely know. Maybe because I have a serious addiction to a game that can suck money like Gaben during a steam sale or maybe it is a new breath of fresh air in the MMO genre with a nice combat system a wide array of play styles and classes and a constantly updated and changing world with a dedicated dev team. If anything proves that I like this game it is the 330+ hours I have spent on it. Try it, love it for the gameplay and hate it for the pay system but don't miss it.

reviewText:
I have been playing neverwinter since beta, and I can say I enjoy the game. The story is interesting the gameplay is fun the graphics are smooth and the setting is just great. There are not many things I have found fault in with neverwinter but some of these are as follows, for an mmo neverwinter feels extremely linear with one quest linking to the next all the way to endgame. Another thing I dont like is endgame, I always get bored but this seems to just be the mmo way atm, there content creator helps somewhat in that user generated content can be pretty great, but it does not completely make up for some of the default content lacking that spark that makes it interesting. Even another thing that rubs me the wrong way is pvp, when the game was a newer release there seemed to be a more active pvp scene but now all the matches seem to me unbalanced and boring.

Now dont think for a second I am going to end the recommendation on a sour note, I had a LOT of fun with the game on all my characters up until the point you start to feel that inevitable mmo fatigue. I recommend you try the game yourself to see if you like it or not, yea end game can be grindy, yea there are some ridiculous cash shop items but are these not things we have all come to expect from a free to play mmo? The game has a lot to offer and a lot of fun you can experience without paying a dime or grinding a second, so get out there and get playing!



Update 7/30/14: Neverwinter fans rejoice, Neverwinter is coming to xbox and its getting a new expansion!

Update 8/11/15: Neverwinter just keeps getting new content. I have not played in a while but this is good news. I hear its one of the most popular free to play games on Xbox now as well!

reviewText:
I don't have thousands of hours on this game like some other people on here but at first play, this game is incredible. Most modern mmorpgs out there are stuck in a rut where everyone in the game is wearing the same armor to get the same stats because there no differences between classes, except for roles.

This game has so much to it. 40 hours of gameplay may get you close to that cap but you are far from done. The complexities of choosing the right moves(sorry infinite hotbar people) choosing the right stats, choosing the right gear, choosing the right abilities will keep you going in this game for a long time.

Comabt is hands down some the best an MMORPG has seen, improving upon the Guild Wars dodge mechanics. PvP is about more than seeing who can run the best circles and press the moves in a better faster rotation, there is actually some skill involved. The missions and story may leave you wishing you cared a little bit more; and maybe got a little more out the quests but the combat system will keep you glued to your seat. Better to have amazing combat and an incredible roleplay speccing system then amazing dialogue and story options.

8/10
Graphics should be better for a game that is a year and a half old
Learning curve is LONG
sometimes patches will leave the game unplayable(is fixed quickly though)
story is weak
dungeons feel a little to short

reviewText:
Positives:
* Good implementation of DnD game mechanics.
* Good combat mechanics.
* Good pace for leveling
* Not terribly easy to screw up your character
* Clear quest succession path
* Handholding is moderately optional

Negatives:
* Bad Voice acting
* Bad plot
* Bad dialog
* Bad Graphics
* Extraordinarily freemium (however that doesn't seem to effect anything outside PvP and player rank)
* You have to pay to make more than two characters, and you have to pay to redistribute points.

Overall, good MMO. Really enjoying it.

reviewText:
I've played this game for a while and I have to say, that many negative things in negative comments are true:

- EndGame PvP is full of players who spend way too much money in a game and just destroy you (there are some guys out there who are stronger then your whole team)
- You really need only 3 classes: Control Wizard, Great Weapon Fighter and only sometimes a Devoted Cleric
- The game repeats over and over again in the EndGame because of campaigns" and the same Dungeons over and over again
- You often end up exploiting bugs in some dungeons and run them over and over again -> grinding as f***

Please notice that I'm NOT familiar with the Books etc. I just started it because a good friend told me about it.

But there are some really good aspects in the game:
+ it looks nice
+ the gameplay is really nice and just makes fun
+ the music is nice
+ real fun with some friends
+ nice map/dungeon design
+ theoreticly you can reach everything without spending any money
date:
but it would take waaaay too long
+ PvE is not Pay2Win

+/- the community: On one side
recommended: they throw you out of the group because you don't have a 15.000+ Gearscore (shows how good your equipment is) - on the other
hoursPlayed: they'll help you and share their experience\n+/- Updates: The game develops more and you get more and more content - but with every update there is at least one new way to exploit a dungeon\n+/- Boss fights: Many of them are unique and are really great ! - But after the 5. to 10. time you kill the same boss
voteText: you'll know how to kill him easily\n+/- The "ZenShop": The ZenShop is a place where you can buy stuff with "Zen"
helpfulPercent: you get them for real money. In this shop you can't buy any equipment but Wards
votesHelpful: and you'll need those wards for your enchantments.\n\nAll in all i can say that I had fun playing this game and I will play it further because after every dungeon you finish
votesTotal: after every boss you kill and after every step you advance you make in the campaigns
votesFunny: you'll feel better and you can see how you develop your character.\nIf you have another opinion pls share it in the comments below.\nIt's a game worth a try because it's free2play :3"

reviewText:
A very fun game, absolutely worth the time you'll spend playing it. To top that off, it's FREE. And though you'll begin very slowly, giving soldiers medkits and collecting broken arrows, the moment you expect a chore, you're fighting the Necromancer's chief in brute strength. From there, you can do anything you so choose, whether that be the plot line or discovering things you aren't supposed to yet.
Every class and race feels individual, as some races change the loadout of your class. It runs off the familiar Stats from DnD, Strangth, Dexterity, Charisma, Constitution, & Wisdom. These stats will effect anything you do. This game requires skill rather than good equipment, unlike WoW, in that you can sidestep and teleport (depending on your class) to escape attacks. You have to have full situational awareness though, because if one enemy can sneak up on you, you're gonna have a bad time.
You can quest with other people, which is fantastic and makes the game much more friendly than  other MMORPGs. There is even a mail system. And though some quests you do feel similar, you won't get bored of them. They never feel repetitive, although they sound like it.

Bottom line is, if you have hard drive space, good internet, and NEED something to keep you occupied for the rest of the year, this game is definately for you.

reviewText: Looking for that good old Neverwinter Nights feel but in an MMO format? Then you'll be sorely disappointed.\n\nI concluded very quickly that this title is Neverwinter in name alone, where the long since established D&D rule system and mechanics are no where in sight. Hence I didn't play for very long out of blinding disappointment. Instead of the second coming we get this weird mix of modern" action orientated combat
date: apparently borrowing mechanics and ideas from a wide range of similar games and throwing them haphazardly into a boiling pot of lore loosely based on the beloved Neverwinter Nights games and D&D universe.\n\nWhere this game has a chance to shine though
recommended:
is through it's surprisingly complex and complete quest creation system. There is a metric tonne of player created quests here (for better or worse)! Some are really well written and thought out while others are painfully incomplete and outright boring.

Would I recommend it?
If you are familiar with the role of being a gamemaster or just love to create stories
hoursPlayed: this might just be the game for you.\nIf you are looking for yet another F2P MMO in which to kill things
voteText:
this might be the game for you.
If you are looking for a solid Neverwinter Nights/D&D experience... keep looking.

TL;DR: Leave your love and expectations of D&D at the door and you should be fine."

reviewText:
First of all this is not a pay to win game. ZEN is a currency you can buy with real money. You can convert ZEN into Astral Diamonds or do the opposite - AD into ZEN. AD can be achieved by doing daily quests and is the trading currency used in the Auction House and several merchants. You can buy ZEN to quicken your progression or make the game more convenient(e.g. extra inventory slots, respec tokens, rare companions and more). ZEN converted into AD can get you rare and powerful items from the Auction House.
Only difference a paying user could have, is if he bought a Starter pack or Guardian of Neverwinter pack and he would receive exclusive gear, mounts/companions, enchants. They barely affect gameplay and only have vanity value, rather than becoming stronger.
All content is the same either you're a paying user or a free user, it depends on how much are you willing to grind. You can grind to get AD and then trade it for something you want. Or be a bit more patient and do daily quests and sell unwanted stuff in the Auction house.
Proffessions are a grind fest and work based of timers. You need a certain leveled/valued worker, reagents and time. Most proffesions have task times of 10-60minutes. Leadership on the other hand has 2-12hours. You can access proffesions from your browser/mobile device so if you're really determined you can progress in proffesions nicely.
Neverwinter is worth a try, for a free-to-play mmo this one is indeed special.

reviewText:
The following is just a prototype outline which I plan on updating as I progress further through the game.

27 hours in and I'm still just 'begining'

The game starts off teasing with an overhead map of the entire AD&D world and asking from which part you hail. Avoiding the cliche of choosing Baldur's Gate" or "Planescape" I opted for a lesser known region of which I've already forgetten the name of.

After your selection the game
recommended:
carries you to the Sword Coast and dumps you smack dab in the middle of Neverwinter. Icewind Dale is there too as a secondary campaign once you've toodely-deed so far through the main romp. On the far side of Neverwinter's main area there is a crew lining up for an exodus to the arctic content but the ship captain will bluntly tell you to come back much later when you're less of a family man.

If you're looking for a challenging single player experience with hefty reflex action combat; NW has strategically placed only a small number of hot keys around the WASD area and you can trip several of them at a time.
Mixed with your shift key
hoursPlayed: space bar and mouse it's just as finger frenzy as the more action-oriented console games.\n\nDespite NW's choice to only focus on the Sword Coast and all overland travel is handled by fast traveling from a static overhead map - Each individual area is huge and some of the areas are laden in secrets
voteText: side quests and dungeons.\n\nI've had nearly thirty hours of quality entertainment so far and haven't spent a dime but there are some massive cash grabs going on - not so much that they are needed to progress but when players gallop by on invisible horses
helpfulPercent: and plow through crowds with mechanical bulls and spiders you realize that the REALLY interesting material pushing NW far beyond a Triple A game is going to cost your time or your wallet.\n\nTime? Yes
votesHelpful: apparently everything that can be purchased for real cash can 'techincally' be purchased with Astral Diamonds but good luck finding many people storing
votesTotal: let alone offering to sell
votesFunny:
their hard earned Zen.  There is a AD exchange for Zen always selectable from the menu along the top of your screen but seldom have I seen other players auctioning their Zen. Neverwinters management doesn't offer it at a base rate themselves so it's up to the players if they want to put real money up for grabs for more 'play' money. Hmm...

But as I've said - I've had more fun in this game for free than most games I've bought over the years for $30 a piece and the material I've got left and overworld map to open up looks nearly endless.

All said and done however NW's fun for me lies in the challenge and suprise of uncovering secrets on on your own - especially doing solo raids. The challenge is balanced perfectly to give a lone wolf like myself a hard time without it becoming unfair. I can easily compare the expperience to the lone wolf challenges in Warframe where it really seemed the game was loading it on heavier to try and choke up your wallet out of frustration but when you socked it to the A.I. you were all like "YEAH! IN YOUR FACE YOU BLODDY DRIPPING ****!!"

I can only imagine having played the previous dungeons with several others and it would've been a total clean-up (especially if the other players were higher level) in those instances the experience might possibly reduce itself to another MMO where everyone stands around chatting in a theme park showing off the funny virtual clothes they bankrupted their parents for."

reviewText:
A very fun game, absolutely worth the time you'll spend playing it. To top that off, it's FREE. And though you'll begin very slowly, giving soldiers medkits and collecting broken arrows, the moment you expect a chore, you're fighting the Necromancer's chief in brute strength. From there, you can do anything you so choose, whether that be the plot line or discovering things you aren't supposed to yet.
Every class and race feels individual, as some races change the loadout of your class. It runs off the familiar Stats from DnD, Strangth, Dexterity, Charisma, Constitution, & Wisdom. These stats will effect anything you do. This game requires skill rather than good equipment, unlike WoW, in that you can sidestep and teleport (depending on your class) to escape attacks. You have to have full situational awareness though, because if one enemy can sneak up on you, you're gonna have a bad time.
You can quest with other people, which is fantastic and makes the game much more friendly than  other MMORPGs. There is even a mail system. And though some quests you do feel similar, you won't get bored of them. They never feel repetitive, although they sound like it.

Bottom line is, if you have hard drive space, good internet, and NEED something to keep you occupied for the rest of the year, this game is definately for you.

reviewText:
I've played this game for a while and I have to say, that many negative things in negative comments are true:

- EndGame PvP is full of players who spend way too much money in a game and just destroy you (there are some guys out there who are stronger then your whole team)
- You really need only 3 classes: Control Wizard, Great Weapon Fighter and only sometimes a Devoted Cleric
- The game repeats over and over again in the EndGame because of campaigns" and the same Dungeons over and over again
- You often end up exploiting bugs in some dungeons and run them over and over again -> grinding as f***

Please notice that I'm NOT familiar with the Books etc. I just started it because a good friend told me about it.

But there are some really good aspects in the game:
+ it looks nice
+ the gameplay is really nice and just makes fun
+ the music is nice
+ real fun with some friends
+ nice map/dungeon design
+ theoreticly you can reach everything without spending any money
date:
but it would take waaaay too long
+ PvE is not Pay2Win

+/- the community: On one side
recommended: they throw you out of the group because you don't have a 15.000+ Gearscore (shows how good your equipment is) - on the other
hoursPlayed: they'll help you and share their experience\n+/- Updates: The game develops more and you get more and more content - but with every update there is at least one new way to exploit a dungeon\n+/- Boss fights: Many of them are unique and are really great ! - But after the 5. to 10. time you kill the same boss
voteText: you'll know how to kill him easily\n+/- The "ZenShop": The ZenShop is a place where you can buy stuff with "Zen"
helpfulPercent: you get them for real money. In this shop you can't buy any equipment but Wards
votesHelpful: and you'll need those wards for your enchantments.\n\nAll in all i can say that I had fun playing this game and I will play it further because after every dungeon you finish
votesTotal: after every boss you kill and after every step you advance you make in the campaigns
votesFunny: you'll feel better and you can see how you develop your character.\nIf you have another opinion pls share it in the comments below.\nIt's a game worth a try because it's free2play :3"

reviewText:
Allow me to start this review by saying that the game in it's basic,free to play version is a decent one to say the least,with a pretty nice community and enjoyable gameplay.Why then am I not recommening this game?

It is common knowledge that these types of games are leaning more and more towards P2W,but while other games might actually care about you if you spend money,not this one.Not if use your Steam Wallet to buy the products at any rate.I used my Steam Wallet to buy some currency called Zen,hoping to sell it in game for quick Astral Diamonds,which is basically the common currency.Not only was I not rewarded the First Time buyer's pack,which is reserved for people who buy directly from Arc,my account was put on Probation: meaning anything I buy is bound to my account and I am unable to sell Zen.You would think a day or two while they verify the payment would be understandable,but it has been a week and a half and I am still on probation.

I thought fine,lets try something else,so I bought Enchanted Keys which let you open Lockboxes,hoping to find a decent item to sell in the Auction House.The keys were also bound but what they fail to mention is EVEN THE REWARDS IN THE LOCKBOXES WILL BE BOUND.So for example if you found a mount selling for around 6million Astral Diamonds which you do not like or already have you're stuck with it.I can almost hear people say Dum*a// of course the rewards will be bound
date: your key was also bound" but you are wrong
recommended: VIP players (and yes I am one) get an Enchanted Key everyday which is also bound
hoursPlayed: however the rewards opened with it are not.\n\nSo to recap
voteText: I do recommend this game in the Free to Play mode

reviewText:
This game is fun, but there are some flaws.

You can grind up a character to lvl 60 in 2.5 days. One day during double xp events easy.

Rogues are horribly overpowered in pvp. Their disables are too long compared to other classes and their damage is too high. Rangers have to channel an instant for 2 seconds to even come close to the same damage, and that gets interrupted on any damage taken.

So, get a rogue, dominate pvp.

reviewText:
(Hours on Steam are incorrect as I used to play with Perfect Worlds launcher and have at least 300 hours+)

I started playing Neverwinter back in open Beta and honestly would have recommended this game to anyone and everyone since I genuinely loved the game back then, I had endless hours of fun and took away a lot of good memories from people I met while playing.

The game sadly went to the dogs though after mod 3 release, it became blatantly P2W (Pay to Win) and if you weren't willing to put your hand in your pocket to deck out your character then you better be damned willing to give up having any kind of life of sorts and 100% commit to playing with short breaks because you will need to grind like you've never ginded before and even then it will probably take you months just to get one item out of many that you require to progress through the game.

Neverwinter is also very quick to permanently banned your account when you've done nothing wrong (Guild members of mine had to make new accounts and start from scratch) oh and that super rare item from that super rare drop that you apparently just got? Yeah, don't get too excited, it hasn't went into your bag.
The customer services suck so don't expect them to help you with anything.

So over all? Great game with lots of potential but yeno... They care more about money than having a great game.

reviewText: Despite all the reactions you'll get from lovers and hater, this game is Free-To-Play, so I do recommend anyone to try it. If you like it, then continue playing it but if you dont, then no harm is done and just uninstall it from your system. It's that easy, cant get easier than that...well you can just not play the game but do you want to do that without satisfying your curiousity? Remember, human is curious of nature (just like cats, except trying this game wont kill ya).\n\nPersonal opinion of the game: I like it and currently liking it a lot since it's based on one of my favorite past time; Dungeons & Dragons (doesn't matter any edition coz I'm a fan of all of it). If you're a real DnD fan and not a DnD purist who tends to stick to just one rule/gameplay, then this is a game for you (mebe just until you finish the main storyline or get to level 60 with 1 or more characters).

reviewText:
This game is great but with some small tiny things that should be improved on. The first one is mouth animations and head movements seem waaaaaaaaayyyy unrealistic and inhuman. They need to make the npc's talking more life like but hey just look like robots opening they're mouths. I know this can be done without much effort, its just time consuming to make a bunch of new face and head animations. Lazy.

Next is the peformance of the game which i may say is terrible considering the graphics in the game are mid ranged. I understand that its a mmorpg and they're are other players in the game and tons of models running around should boggle down my system but seriously the lvls where they're are only enemies and npc's should run smoothly but they don't. There needs to be better optimization of the video cards that work with the game im talking about AMD and ATI cards.

I have two cards on 2 different systems my nvidia 640 works well but my ati 4850 which by the way is faster and better performing then the recommended 2900 gt runs wayyyyy slow. Thats a no no.

Last probably something I havent figured out on the controls but attack dash or whatever you call it should bigger or maybe im missing something i just need to customize it because as you get to higher lvls you get more skills and I want to be able to use ALL my skills not the juts 3 on my action dash. Lame.

Don't let me start on Qeue for dungeons cause its hella annoying sitting there for like 2 hours so that 1 person would join instead of spamming the LFG channel to get someone to party with you to do a dungie. I DONT UNDERSTAND WHY WHEN IM QEUE FOR DUGEONS AND FOR A SPECIFIC ONE everyone in the channel is LFG for that same dungeon. We shouldn't have beg other players to be like hey man wanna do a dungeon. Or you message someone whos been spamming the channel and they tell you that they already have people its just annoying and inconsistent. YOU GUYS ARE WASTING PEOPLES PRECIOUS TIME.

Even thought this game has its faults the game is excellent the enemies and the lore and crafting is awesome.

The companion thing is pretty awesome too.

reviewText:
This game used to be amazing I played most of my time on Xbox One and i still think its a brilliant game but my review is based on how it is now and not the fun ive had in the past.

Effectivly all the content before you hit a platau is to get you hooked in the story is pretty unimaganitive its all about better loot as are all MMOs really. Once you cap you have weeklys and dungeons/the real campaign but to really get anywhere in this game its hugly pay to win. want a decent mount above 80% speed how about 10 pound minimum spend...how about a new decent companion? yep 10 pound minimum spend. Expansion for the game how about 40 pound and theres a few. I bought the Dragon expansion a mount a companion and a few other things and realised even then i was nowhere i end up spending 80 pound to hit another platau and before i could even get to where most of my clan where the game would have expected me to pay 200 - 500 pounds.

The game is infact VERRYYY expencive and it tries to hook you in with the first buy then you think ohh i cant go back now just no its a game with no real replayability unless your willing to spend a fortune. You cant even make that much in game money that yes is transferable to real money to buy stuff but untill you have spent to much the more you spend the more you make.

very very pay to play if you want a game you can keep playing without having to spend more and more money then id not recomend this game at all.

as my old mate Admiral Ackbar said ITS A TRAP!"
